name: Verify interoperability of standards (ST 5661 MARIX)
description:
Maritime C2 Information Exchange (MARIX), is a new draft standard which intends to allow a richer sharing of data whilst maintaining backward compatibility for legacy systems.

DPC D&G:
Standardization Need and Impact on Interoperability: In NATO, Maritime Situational Awareness (MSA) is primarily delivered by the building and dissemination of a Recognized Maritime Picture (RMP). NATO does not own a technical standard able to do this; both the Alliance (Allies and the NATO Enterprise) use a USA standard for these purposes. This standard, Over The Horizon Targeting Gold (OTH-T-Gold) received its last update in 2007 and the USA has confirmed that OTH-T-Gold will not receive any further technical updates to meet the semantically rich demands of the modern warfighter. To meet current MSA requirements within the Maritime domain, as well as those emerging through NATO’s Digital Transformation and Multi Domain Operations (MDO) the Nations and Strategic Commands represented at the C3 Concepts and Requirements (Maritime) Capability Team (MC3 CaT) have agreed that something must be done and that NATO should develop or adopt a profile that can be configuration managed by the Alliance. These requirements are now contained within the 2023 Federated Mission Networking (FMN) Spiral Specification Roadmap in Spiral 6. The Maritime Command and Control and Battlespace Management Swimlane, or OSW-3, contains such detail in its Spiral Objectives and Capability Enhancements. A profile within a Allied Data Publication (ADatP), ratified and promulgated in readiness for the preferred Spiral 6 timelines (NED 2030), aligns to the delivery of NATO’s Digital Transformation, MDO, DCS, NCDF (now also Spiral 6) and FMN Milestone 3.

The new information exchange profile shall provide Maritime data in support of MDO; it shall be able to share data in accordance with latest NATO information sharing techniques as detailed within the NATO Core Data Framework (NCDF); it shall meet security requirements as detailed within Data Centric Security (DCS); it shall allow metadata labelling and binding; it shall remain compatible with legacy Alliance wide specifications for RMP building and dissemination; it shall be compatible with Message Text Formats (MTF) taken from the NATO Message Catalogue built from the rules contained in ADatP-03, and shall be able to function in a Command and Control Denied and Degraded Environment (C2D2E).

name: Information exchange between different security domains
description: Information exchange between different security domains.

name: (DYMS 25) Interoperability of unmanned systems and integration with MUS C2 capabilities
description:
Exploring and experimenting with unmanned systems (these could be not limited to Maritime but coming from  multiple domains) to test interoperability and integration with Maritime Unmanned Systems (MUS) C2 capabilities.

This objective is strongly linked to '''de-risking Dynamic Messenger. DYMS '25''' will take place Sep 2025.

Potential to integrate MUS into TDL.

name: Maritime C2 system performance tests
description:
Many Maritime C2 systems have proven to be interoperable, now we want to examine and compare how these systems handle the data and perform tasks on this data. These examinations will focus on:

(1) RMP compilation and picture management -- how tracks are associated, correlated or merged. How ambiguities are created.

(2) WSM receipt/creation of PMI data and interference checking IAW ATP18 and ATP01vol1.

(3) White track capacity on systems producing WSP.

Intention is to also focus on the testing of new MCCIS7 filling the gap for MCCIS life extension plus any new capability identified thru Project Proteus CPP.

name: Examination of sharing of RMP, COP and info in multidomain environment
description:
Exam of disseminating of Recognised Maritime Picture (RMP), Common Operational Picture (COP) and related info in a multidomain environment.

The RMP is a geographic presentation of processed, all-source contact and planning data of surface, subsurface, amphibious, maritime air units, ground forces, and operations in designated Areas of Responsibility (AOR).

The RMP directly supports the C2 of maritime forces by providing commanders at each level of command with information relevant

The purpose is to:
* Evaluate and validate interoperability of available information by the assigned C2 System for a given AOR.
* Evaluate and validate level of readiness for disseminating RMP, COP by the assigned C2 System.

name: Assess the maturity of MIP 4.4 in Command and Control System implementation
description:
This objective will allow CC-Leads to examine their (near) fieldable implementation of the MIP 4.4 in their C2 system. The tests should provide insight in technical conformance. Type-results of tests:

Technical Tests and Operational Tests.

name: Assess the maturity of MIP 3.1 in Command and Control System implementation
description:
This is the main MIP 3.1 objective in order to support all technical testing and the parent of the MIP 3.1 AV&V objective.  

This objective will allow CC-Leads to examine their (near) fieldable implementation of the MIP 3.1 in their C2 system. The tests should provide insight in technical conformance. Type-results of tests:

Technical Tests and Operational Tests like:
* BSO (Battle Space Objects)
* Units symbols (different Hostillity)
* Tactictal Graphics
* Task and Events
* MOOTW (Military Operation other Than War)
* Materiel
* Dismounted Individuals

Optional Service Functions like:
* ORBAT
* Holdings
* Plans and Orders (Overlay/Textual)

name: Explore and experiment with exchanging MIP information using the Cross COI for JV (MIP, OpCmd)
description: Providing MIP-IES v4.4 data to, and consuming data from the XCOI Datalake.

name: Assess the maturity of MIP 4 specifications an cross-security-domain filtering abilities (MIP)
description: This objective has to purposes. First to examine their (near) fieldable implementation of the MIP4-IES specifications in an unclassified environment. Secondly to perform MIP message forwarding between different security domains with the use as Information Exchange Gateways (IEG) and test the implementation of the STANAG 4774 / 4778 specifications.

name: Command and Control in a Denied Degraded Environment (C2D2E) testing
description:
Having access to SATCOM in the Maritime domain is not a given and (Primary, Alternate, Contingency, Emergency) PACE communications options under a C2D2E situation dictate the need to be able to operate C2 within the HF spectrum.

Intention is to use a mediator to throttle the network to simulate HF bandwidth constraints for all testing within this objective.

name: eXamine systems’ conformance to the NATO APP-11 Message Catalogue
description:
eXamine systems’ conformance to the NATO APP-11 Message Catalogue:
APP-11 C Original (Baseline 13.1)
APP-11 C Change 1 (Baseline 14)
APP-11 D (Baseline 15)

MTF:
//-MTF
XML-MTF

name: Asset Tracking Adoption & Integration
description:
A supply chain, or operations logistics chain as NATO terms it, consists of multiple parties working together to support the mission of the NATO commander. Information is essential to the integration and coordination of those parts. Without it, logistics processes will not successfully execute transactions and leaders will make ill-informed choices. The in-transit visibility that asset tracking information provides underpins decision-making that improves logistics chain performance.

When capabilities crucial to a mission are moving between one location and another along a logistics chain, it is easy to lose sight of them. In-transit visibility is a picture of their movement. Realizing that picture involves identifying the traceable objects the picture must contain and tracking them from their point of origin to their eventual destination. Such asset tracking allows a commander to:
* Know where an item is and where it has been during transportation
* Expedite a shipment when priorities change
* Optimize transport solutions, either for cost or speed or both
* Create opportunities for multinational collaboration
* Reduce the number of lost items
* Trace items that do get lost in the course of shipment
* Continually plan and improve wider supply chain performance

Achieving these ends Alliance-wide requires the creation of an interoperable collection of national asset-tracking capabilities. Few nations, nor NATO, possess such a capability that exploits all the advantages offered by Automatic Identification and Data Capture (AIDC). AIDC covers a spectrum of technologies and devices that capture, aggregate and transfer data from a range of data carriers to information systems. Such carriers include linear and 2-dimensional barcodes, active radio frequency identification tags and sophisticated sensor and GPS-enabled tags.

The goal of asset tracking testing in CWIX 2025 is to build on the recent series of tests undertaken during CWIX cycles since 2020. This will involve the continued examination of NATO standards that are promulgated or in final draft prior to entry into ratification. Those standards will almost certainly form the basis for the asset tracking element of the service instruction that is anticipated for inclusion in FMN Spiral 7.

Because the approved status of the standards is in the vanguard of FMN Spiral 7, exploration of asset tracking within that spiral is inappropriate: The standards that will make up the service instruction have been explored, experimented with and examined as part of CWIX trials since 2020. Consequently CWIX25 testing involving them will entail a mix of experimentation and examination according to the maturity of the capabilities involved in the tests. In effect, participating capabilities will be engaged in a draft form of assurance, verification and validation of asset tracking interoperability under FMN. In support of that, all areas of testing will continue to involve the thorough and methodical collection of test data and its storage within the CWIX wiki repository. 

Beyond the generalized description of the objective, the specific aims of testing are to further improve in-transit visibility by:
* Experimenting with new or emerging national adopters of asset tracking capabilities
* Offering the (previously-experimental, now-fielded) asset tracking branch of NATO's LOGFAS capability as a trials partner that provides either a national (or NATO) C2 asset-tracking capability or a local asset-tracking solution
* Examining the implementation of NATO's standardized business processes, messages and system architecture in participating asset tracking capabilities - including through information exchange between lower and higher security domains - with the aim of verifying and validating them through system instantiations in CWIX
* Examining alternative active RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) and mobile, app-based barcode-tracking solutions from commercial sources alongside nationally developed government and in-house NATO solutions
* Experimenting with the ability of those alternative technologies to interoperate and be integrated with 3rd party asset-tracking network components
* Experimenting with automated distribution and mediation services for the sharing of messages between asset-tracking network partners

With regard to the third bullet immediately above (concerning information exchange across security domains), this objective's description of asset tracking adoption and integration must be considered alongside [[OBJ-015]] and vice versa.

name: IRM CM System AEDP19 Ed.4
description:
Testing multiple different IRM CM systems.
IRM CM stands for Intelligence Requirement Management and Collection Management.
IRM CM within JISR, has to meet STANAG 4559 ie AEDP19 ed.4.

The CSD servers and clients are at various level of maturity.

Test plans will consider :
* AEDP19 processes relative to the servers,
* relative to the clients, 
* use cases for AFSC (awacs replacement).

name: Asset Tracking Multi-Domain Operations C2
description:
This objective is a sub-set of its sister, asset tracking adoption and integration, [[OBJ-012]]. Both texts should be read together. Introductory material on the nature of asset tracking and in-transit visibility appears under the other objective.

Military asset tracking networks, like their civilian counterparts, are designed to work in an unclassified environment most of the time - or at least below the level of the CWIX Pink enclave. This permits the fullest exploitation of the internet, allowing greater speed, coverage, transparency and information fidelity as packages move across different transportation networks. But in crisis and war, the in-transit visibility picture must be reproducible on classified networks and, where required, the unclassified picture enhanced with classified data. This objective tests the ability to achieve this goal. The aim is to extend previous efforts to share information across security domains and, in doing so, present a more current and accurate picture to the NATO commander, national commanders and their logistic commanders.

Asset tracking trials partners have agreed three broad CWIX25 testing goals to support this aim:
* Complete information exchanges across the entire suite of standardized asset tracking messages in order to examine the ability to create an in-transit visibility picture relating to shipments of freight.
* Undertake experimental cross-domain sharing of asset tracking information from capabilities in a lower classification domain to others in a higher classification domain.
* Experiment with message labelling in line with NATO's data centric security standards.

name: CORBA Replacement with REST
description:
Testing the replacement of Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) with the Representational state transfer (REST) architecture as required is Federated Mission Networking (FMN) Spiral 6.

CORBA is the technology used for the main interface with an AEDP-17 CSD server, and required in '''AEDP-17 EdA V1'''. This technology has long been discontinued and unsupported. An alternative interface relying on SOAP web services is also specified, covering the main ''client-to-server'' use cases, but missing the key ''server-to-server'' capability.

A new interface covering all such use cases and thus fully replacing CORBA, based on REST architecture, has been specified in '''AEDP-17 EdA V3''' (not promulgated, but taken as reference applicable document by the community), and will be foreseeably enforced in '''EdB V1'''. 

This interface was already explored and experimented in CWIX23 and CWIX24, focusing on the API ''server capabilities''. For CWIX25, it is expected to augment the scope with experimentation of ''client capabilities''.

Expectations on participant capabilities:

* '''Server CC:''' Single testing on compliance with the specification; provider-consumer (two-way) testing on the sync endpoint with a peer Server CC; provider testing on client-to-server TC.
* '''Client CC:''' consumer testing on client-to-server TC
* '''Guard CC:''' (simulated) mediator testing intercepting server-to-server TC

name: Experiment with DCS on ISR data
description: Experiment with STANAG 4774 labelling within a CSD

name: Intelligence BSO Synchronization
description: Synchronize Intel BSO's according to AIntP-3. The exchange mechanism will be based on the APP-11 E versions of the relevant messages;  UNITINTEREC, PLACEINTREC, EQUIPINTREC, BIOINTREC, EVENTINTREC and INTRELREC. The most basic exchange is to publish messages for each object in a shared folder (file or web) where other systems poll any updates. If possible, a REST-based exchange may be experimented with aiming for Spiral 6.

name: Experiment and validate new Information Management capabilities for STANAG 4559 Edition 5
description:
Experiment and validate new information management capabilities for STANAG 4559 Edition 5, addressing shortfalls identified in STANAG 4559 Edition 4. The STANAG 4559 edition 5 capabilities will be experimented using STANAG 4559 Edition 4 implementations with fully backward compatible extensions.

STANAG 4559 Edition 5 is expected to be available  in 2027. In current phase engineers will experiment with new interoperability solutions and assess suitability of near term implementation in products by industry.  For 2026 it is expected this objective will brought to examination. National fielding will be short after 2027, FMN fielding is planned between 2030 and 2032. 

New information management capabilities addressed  under this objective, having interoperability impact:

1 STANAG 5636 implementation: NATO standard core meta data set and new confidentiality labeling for information objects.

2 Hard deletion: capability to remove destroy network wide information objects which have security or legal implications e.g. due to human error.

3 Soft deletion: capability to remove information objects from the view of the operator (irrelevant information, duplicates).

4 Archiving/backup: removal of information objects from synchronizing servers to free system resources.

5 Management of multiple operations: relate  STANAG 4559 information objects to operations, enabling management of multiple operations on the same servers/network. 

6 Pagination: AEDP-19 misses a capability to paginate requested objects. For large amounts of objects this poses a limitation.

name: JISR Monitoring
description:
Explore the Monitoring capabilities of Coalition Shared Data (CSD) servers, as currently in development by STANAG 4559 CST (Custodian Support Team), with prospect to be included in future Edition 5 of that standard.

The Monitoring capability requires a new interface deployed alongside a CSD, the Topology service. This Topology service supports the following functionalities:
* Exposes information about its companion CSD: library identification, technical information (IP, hostnames), supported capabilities (AEDP-17, AEDP-18, AEDP-19...), exposed endpoints, links to other CSDs, application level behavior and status for the CSD
* Collection and aggregation of the same information provided by partner Topology services

By supporting these two functionalities, the Topology service is able to provide a common picture on the status of the topology of the CSDs, helping in identifying remote points of failure or bottlenecks, while also providing standardized information of the configuration of the CSDs (what would be collected by JMEI documents).

A third functionality is also included within the scope of this OBJ consisting of visualizing in real-time the information provided by one such Topology service in a dashboard-like tool.

Expectations on participant capabilities, up to the scope of each particular capability (in order of ambition):
# Testing compliance to the draft specification of the Topology service in single pattern testing
# Testing dissemination of the information from your Topology service to others (and the other way around) in provider-consumer testing
# Visualization of the information of the Topology service in a dashboard in single pattern testing

The goal with the testing is focused on furthering the development of the specification of the Monitoring capability.

name: Test MCM C2 system with other MC2IS to support DYMS
description:
Test Mine Warfare C2, specifically M-Cube and de-risk prior to Dynamic Messenger '25.

Testing to include APP-11 messages relevant to MCM Operations. 

Testing MCUBE for potential use to Standing Naval Staff onboard CTG 441.03 and CTG 441.04.

name: Examine JISR picture in MD SOC and JTF COP
description: Provide (exercise) timely, relevant, and correct JISR picture to strategic and operational level decision makers in COP. Include (examine) open-source information across security domains. Include (examine) the integration of coalition shared database (CSD) into the picture with metadata tagged video and images.

name: Examine Reporting and COP management process
description: Examine the draft ACO directive 080-080 and SCO Reports and Returns for reporting and COP management within the NATO Command structure using directed formats and corrects authoritative data sources or other means of information exchange.

name: eXamine and eXperiment the NATO's NI2CE messenger application connection with JChat
description: Examine, experiment the use of a NATO messaging tool to exchange non-classified information across security domains. This Objective aims at testing the exchange of information across security domains (non-classified to green/pink), as well as the interoperability of two different messaging systems, one sitting in the non-classified environment (NI2CE) and the other in the classified (JChat). This test wants to experiment the message exchange between these two platform which could invaluably enhance SHAPE MDSOC's recall activities in both crisis and/or current operations.

name: eXperiment cross-COI information search and data analytics for Multi-Domain Situational Awareness
description: Experiment NATO's innovative search and data retrieval engines, such as the NCDF Data Lake Diver MVP to access better and faster information across all operational and functional area systems, from both national and NATO systems, exploiting the NCDF Data Lake. Experiment the introduction of LLM prototype MDO.ai to provide enhanced data and predictive analytics to support MDC2 operators to elaborate information found in the authoritative data sources in a timely manner.

name: Experiment and Examine cross-tool force readiness/generation reporting
description:
Experiment and Examine cross-tool force readiness reporting using executability and readiness dashboards, interoperability dashboards, TOPFAS RRT and other tools. 
Reporting to be initiated by nations, later to be disseminated across the dashboards and other tools.

name: FMN SP6/7 Core and Collaboration
description: De-risk the current set of FMN SP6/7 Core and Collaboration SIs and PIs

name: FMN SP6/7/8/+ Core and Collaboration
description:
eXplore potential FMN SP6/7/8/+ Core and Collaboration services

Based on the affiliates intent the focus is on:
* Federation Identity Enrolment
* SCIM
* WebRTC
* Digital Certificates / PKI

In addition to these topics, there will be further experimentation with regard to audio routing approaches.

Comment on the FMN Spirals - this Objective is intended to be overarching for the entire future FMN Core Services exploration.

name: Data Centric Security oriented eXploration and eXperimentation
description:
This is the parent of Data Centric Security objectives regarding eXploration and eXperimentation. The sub-objectives will focus on
* compliance to current STANAGs 4774, 4778 and 5636
* confirmation of STANAG Modification Proposals
* eXploration of FMN SP7/+ 
* eXploration of ACP 240 v2

name: Cloud Integration, Accelerated Deployment, and AI Solutions
description:
eXplore services and capabilities not already on the FMN roadmap : 
* Cloud services
* Secure Cloud
* Rapid Deployment
* Artificial Intelligence Interoperability 
* Usage of LLMs
* Standardization of LLM Platforms
* Standardization of LLM APIs

Testing will be done on BOTH green and pink networks (depending on CC requirements/abilities) but NO cross security domain experiments and tests will be done. Some of the systems will be available on both enclaves, some will be available on only one of the two.

name: FMN-over-PCN (FMN-Fullstack)
description:
Test (once more) the impact of a dynamic PCN carrier network, via the obligatory Type One cryptos, on the FMN services in a Colored Cloud. Both enclaves (Standalone Unclassified for PCN and the Pink Enclave for the FMN services) are required for these full stack test.

Test partners from both security environments are to document their findings/test result under the same objective.

The requirement for the PCN carrier network is essentially that it shall be as dynamic as possible. The impact of FMN compliant QoS marking is to be documented, while the transport network is transferring cross traffic (from simulated additional mission participants), in a bandwidth restricted environment. 

The goal is to measure the impact on as many Core and CoI services as possible.

name: SCIP in a FMN context
description:
Continue the eXploration of different SCIP (SCIP 213.x, 214.2, 233.x) standards as part of a FMN deployment.
Install and operate SCIP Gateways between different coloured clouds.

name: eXploration of NCDF
description: Allow for eXploration and eXperimentation on NCDF centric topics (as opposed to deploying NCDF as a service)

name: eXploration of Learning Tools
description: To explore and assess interoperability between NATO training systems and national individual training technologies, including Learning Management Systems (LMS) and other advanced training platforms. The focus will be on identifying opportunities for seamless integration, ensuring efficient data exchange, and enhancing the delivery of training across NATO and partner nations. Additionally, to analyze technological solutions that support standardized processes, interoperability testing, and future advancements in training technology to improve collective readiness and collaboration.

name: eXamination and eXperimentation on PKI (GREEN)
description: FMN SP 5 PKI validation tests, based on CPWG PKI syndicate requirements and eXperimentation on Unclass PKI for further spiral development (6+), specially PKI data exchange between different security domains

name: Post Quantum Security (GREEN)
description:
Continue eXploration on Post Quantum Algorithms.

Special focus is on the migration from pre-PQ to post-PQ

name: eXploration of XMPP/DCS
description:
eXploration of FMN SP7 mechanisms for XMPP with DCS 1/2 support
Validate which types of XMPP messages need to be passed through a guard to come to a fully functional system.

Explore the labelling of a chatroom, and possible consequences.

For chatrooms, experiment with the options:
- to let the user label selectively every message to the chatroom, or
- to force the UA to label the message with the label defined by the chatroom

The results _may_ influenece the ongoing FMN Spiral 6 discussions, the current expectation is the intended use within the SP7 timeframe.

name: eXperiment, eXamine and eXercise GeoMetOc Services provision
description:
This objective represents the main test scenario for dissemination of GeoMetOc information to all domains (including but not restricted to Air, Land, Sea, Space …). The goal is to provide suitable geo-information to support operational needs/requirements in specific scenarios to other FAs.

The objective also exercises the feeding of GeoMetOc information into the Joint Vignette.

We examinate FMN Spiral 5 SI for Geo by providing data and services according to these specifications.

Experimentation focuses on the provision of MetOc information which is included in FMN Spiral 6 SI for Geo.

name: eXamine compliance with FMN SP5 for Geospatial Information
description:
Assess compliance of national implementations with FMN Spiral 5 Service Instructions for Geospatial Information.
This is a risk reduction event rather than formal Spiral 5 testing.

name: eXperiment & eXplore the provision and consumption Geospatial Data for FMN SP6+
description:
eXperiment and explore the provision of data according to standards new or updated/expanded in FMN Spiral 6+ SI: 
*Defence Geospatial Information Framework (DGIF) 3, which is the basis for NATO Geospatial Information Framework (NGIF) 3 (AGeoP11) as data schema and packed and presented as GeoPackage database container format.
*Defence Gridded Elevation Data (DGED) 1.3 (AGeoP30)

name: eXperiment the provision and consumption of Processing Services for FMN SP6
description:
eXperiment the provision and consumption of Processing Services. For FMN Spiral 6 the following processes were defined:
* distance & area measurements
* line of sight
* viewshed analysis
* elevation profile

This needs to include input/output parameters for each of the use cases.

The Web Processing Service (WPS) is an OGC standard that defines how to implement any geographic calculation or model (i.e. " processes ") as a web service. The WPS interface standardizes the way processes and their inputs/outputs are described, how a client can request the execution of a process, and how the output from a process is handled.

The draft process descriptions are available at DGIWG and will be added to the objective. The implementation could be any version of WPS or even OGC API Processes.

name: eXperiment Geospatial Catalogue Services for FMN SP6: GeoMetOc Products Registration and Discovery
description: Objective related with [[SPO-34]] / [[CPE-296]] , through the usage of Catalogue Service for the Web (CSW) and web service discovery technologies in general, and a standardized metadata format (STANAG 2586 NGMP / AGeoP 08).

name: eXperiment the file-based exchange of METOC data and products for FMN SP6
description: Objective related with [[SPO-318]] / [[CPE-667]] , through the usage file formats such as NetCDF, GeoTIFF, GRIB2, JPEG 2000, GML and GeoJSON.

name: eXperiment service-based dissemination of METOC data and products for FMN SP6
description: Objective related with [[SPO-318]] / [[CPE-668]] , through the adoption of existing OGC Web Service Standards such as WMS, WMTS, WFS and WCS. For WMS, the Time and Elevation dimensions need to be implemented, following OGC Best Practices "OGC 12-111r1 (2014)".

name: eXplore emerging OGC APIs for FMN SP7+
description: Explore emerging OGC API standards (EDR, Features, Maps, Tiles, Records) and associated profiles such as the EDR profile by DGIWG for potential implementation into future FMN Spirals. It will also support the demonstration related testing of new national capability configurations (Gazetteer)

name: eXplore the provision and consumption of Vector Tiles for FMN SP7+
description:
Following last CWIXs, we recommended to further explore and experiment the benefits of vector tiles. The CWIX 2024 and before demonstrated some major benefits regarding network bandwidth, client-based styling, etc.

This objective aims to support a necessary decision making process towards a common format/encoding: open (mapbox tiles in conjunction with OGC API Tiles) and proprietary (ESRI Vector Tile Package) solutions are available.

name: eXplore the provision and consumption of Processing Services for FMN SP7+
description: eXplore the provision and consumption of Processing Services for FMN Spiral 7+ by expanding the processes defined for FMS Spiral 6 (elevation related). Come up with suggestions for processes to be described for FMS Spiral 7+. The implementation could be any version of WPS or even OGC API Processes.

name: eXperiment & eXamine GeoMetOc testing automation solutions
description:
This OBJ is addressed to Geospatial Service providers of all different stages of maturity.

The use of test automation solutions in order to assess the compliance of systems to geospatial standards and profiles is inevitable since the number and complexity of the tests to be conducted exceeds the capacity of individuals doing these tests manually at testing venues like CWIX or CIAV test events. We have to come up with a workable solution to conduct these compliance tests and foster the integration into the CIAV testing tool framework.

CWIX25 will provide an opportunity to continue exploring GeoMetOc testing automation solutions including FGSIT and CITE Team Engine.

General goals for this objective include:

* Validation of testing automation solutions and verifying expected results.
* Demonstrating efficiency gains, over manual methods.
* Detecting gaps, endorsing further development considerations and priorities.
* Promoting/sharing testing automation solutions and receiving feedback that can lead to usability improvements.
* Comparing different solutions, and identifying complementary use cases for them.

Solution-specific goals are as follows:

FGSIT:

* Continue to evaluate all compliance requirements FGSIT can and can not automate (inventory).
* Demonstrate and utilize FGSIT repair services (server side Geoprocessing tools).

CITE Team Engine:

* Implement a CITE Team Engine instance to make OGC Executable Test Suites available for compliance testing.

name: Interoperability of Waveforms and Waveform Specific Testing (NATO NBWF, ESSOR, ...)
description:
Test interoperability of waveforms including the air interface to facilitate multinational missions (NBWF, ESSOR, ...).

Interoperability of waveforms is an important aspect in coalition operations. The exchange of physical radios between coalition partners to be able to communicate is very inflexible and brings many problems. Instead, software defined radios with their ability to load signal processing and higher communication layers dynamically as software modules facilitate the use of coalition waveforms in addition to national waveforms.

name: Radio Integration & Service Discovery
description:
Test the integration of radios into a heterogeneous tactical network including discovery mechanisms and access to additional radio services.

Next generation tactical networks will orchestrate different waveforms in order to combine higher data rates with long range and anti-jam capabilities. In order to combine different waveforms, a routing mechanism is needed that can decide which technology to use best at every hop of the communication path. The objective focuses on the interface between the radios and the routing instance (which can be integrated or external). This includes the data plane as well as the control plane.

Control plane information can include route, link, and path information from the radios but also the announcement of services in the radio like SIP/VoIP based voice and should facilitate self-configuration between the radio and the router functionality. On a data plane level it is important to ensure correct forwarding of IPv4 and IPv6 data including their support protocols.

In addition, Software Defined Networking (SDN) based interfaces to configure radio behavior and to acquire status information from the radio are in scope.

The scope of this objective is from Exploration to Examination:
* Explore standards and concepts that may be relevant for future FMN spirals (e.g. SIP integration).
* Experiment with existing standards to idenfity the potential for FMN (e.g. advanced tactical voice integration).
* Examine the interoperability of near-fielded or fielded systems regarding FMN Spiral 5 or non-FMN functionality.

There is no general requirement on the maturity of participating systems. Systems may be experimental or developmental, as long as test case requirements are met. Nevertheless, testing with fielded or near-fielded systems can provide an additional benefit in terms of test results.

name: Coalition Routing Interoperability
description:
Test the coalition router to router interoperability in a mobile tactical environment (tactical router).

Tactical routing is a key building block for realizing a federated coalition network at the mobile tactical edge.

Tactical routing solutions should be able to combine different radio technologies within a tactical communication environment to take advantage of different waveforms. In addition different tactical routing protocols or different configurations may be present in different parts of the network. Interoperability between them is essential.

Several architectural approaches to mobile tactical routing have been identified and are described by NATO STO IST-124. This includes (interconnect) flat as well as overlay approaches.

For the flat architecture, implementations of the same protocol of different nations must be interoperable with each other to ensure a connected network. In addition, it is also essential to be able to connect different network segments. This is due to scalability reasons but also to facilitate the use of different tactical routing protocols e.g. from different nations.

The overlay architecture aims to create an hierarchical overlay network across multiple nations' networks and transmission technologies, providing an overview of the tactical coalition network and connectivity throughout, while making use of local tactical routing protocols as much as possible. It requires an inter-domain or overlay solution that can handle mobility, disruptions and changes in network segmentation and hierarchy. Different proposals need to be compared and adjusted to support realistic mobility scenarios.

In 2023 the IST-202 research group was formed to provide a clear way forward for Federated Tactical Networking. The objective is to define the possibilities and impossibilities when it comes to enabling federated networking at the tactical edge, including a DDIL-environment. Aspects include routing, (network) security, and federated management of a network that is largely built of different kinds of military waveforms. Also, the different options when it comes to the federated use of and boundaries between national capabilities and coalition capabilities at the tactical edge must be investigated.

Identification of potential (operational and technical) goals for federated tactical networking
* (Routing) protocols for federated tactical networking: multicast and unicast
* Security solutions for federated tactical networking
* Management of a federated tactical network
* Quality of service provisioning for a federated tactical network
* Architecture/approaches for integration of the federated tactical network with the rest of the mission network, which is based on PCN

With respect to the scope below:
* Exploration: Exploring new solutions for tactical routing and federated tactical networking (SP7).
* Experimentation: Experimenting with multicast relaying and forwarding (SP6).
* Examination: Examining forwarding mechanisms from COMMS SIs (SP5).

name: eXplore and eXperiment the provision of pointclouds and 3D data
description:
Provide multi-sensor-data - georeferenced pictures (360°), georeferenced trajectory (tracks), and georeferenced laser point clouds which allow precise measurements and evaluations. Test the generation of 3D products and test various ways of exchanging data and products between participants.

Experiment with the exchange of 3D Formats that will tentatively be part of FMN SP7+ (3D Point clouds).

name: Application & Middleware over Radio (QoS, Network Awareness, …)
description:
Test the application and middleware over tactical radio networks, including interfaces for network awareness and Quality of Service.

In a tactical environment, communication resources are scarce and communication often suffers from impairments e.g. in terms of delay and reliability.

As network conditions vary depending on mobility and external influences, a static adjustment of application and middleware is often not sufficient. Instead, applications, middleware, and network should exchange information to cope with these influences. Besides QoS signaling and data exchange, the network can provide topology and reachability information to the middleware. This information can be processed and relayed to the different services.

Accordingly, in addition to network awareness and QoS interfaces, applications and middleware need to be tested if they can cope with the impairments of the tactical edge.

name: Coalition Security
description:
Test security architectures and mechanisms.

Security architectures and mechanisms manifest on different levels of the protocol stack. Together, they form the overall security concept to protect the data exchanged. This objective focuses on mechanisms up to the application level.

name: eXplore Emerging GeoMetOC technologies and workflows
description:
This objective investigates novel workflows and emerging technologies to improve the GeoMetOc communities capabilities.
It will also support the demonstration related testing of new national capability configurations (WebApps, Gazetteer).

name: Coalition Management
description:
Test management systems for networks and security mechanisms.

Security management, network management, and radio frequency planning for communication systems play a crucial role in the preparation of every mission, as well as in the daily operation of a coalition network. In a coalition environment, these systems need to blend into a federated concept of operation. This can also include the exchange of information between different national management systems. For FMN, the systems should be aligned with NMCD (network management and cyber defense) functionality from PCN.

name: Network Architectures (IPv6, SDN, CCN, NDN, …)
description:
Test Network architectures including evolutionary protocols like IPv6 and SDN but also revolutionary mechanisms like Content Centric Networking and Named Data Networking.

The maturity level of the CCs in respective program-related OBJs can include anything from Experimental to Fielded.

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spirals 4 for PCN
description:
*Improve Test Templates and Test Cases based on "lessons-learned" from previous exercises
*Improve Join-/Maintain and Exit (JMEI) processes to support future exercises and operations
*Improve knowledge and skills in domain name system and certificate operations
*Verify FMN Service Instructions and Procedural Instructions on high detail level
*Demonstrate interoperability in medium sized scenario
*Demonstrate day-zero-readiness
*Develop Information Exchange Services on NMCD to support C2 with realtime graphical PCS Operational Picture
*Support other Objectives and Capabilities with a well designed fully operational PCN

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spirals 5 for PCN
description:
*Improve Test Templates and Test Cases based on "lessons learned" from previous exercises
*Improve knowledge and skills in domain name system and certificate operations
*Verify updated FMN Service Instructions and Procedural Instructions first time
*Examine Quality of Service implementation in detail
*Examine data traffic end to end in detail (speed, jitter, latency, throughput)
*Examine anycast DNS
*Verify or confirm MTU-size specifications of the Service Instructions

To work on this high technical level it is absolutely mandatory to setup a basic PCN fast and fully operational, that means to demonstrate zero-day-capabilties in real life.

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 6 for PCN STATIC
description:
'''This Objective provides a testbed for developing and exploring technologies and solutions to support static FMN Protected Core Network implementations.'''

This static, permanent and non-deployable PCN is the backbone to connect
deployed multinational missions. So this Objective additionally explores
designs, technologies and solutions to federate deployable PCNs based on
Spiral 4 or 5 with the static PCN based on Spiral 6.

Finally this Objective is one multinational Protected Core formed by one static PCN
and a various number of deployable PCNs representing different, individual missions.

While deployable PCN solutions have reached a high maturity level and are 
available as fielded systems there is a high demand to develop an interoperable
static PCN solution based on FMN Spiral 6 to enable the seamless connection 
of deployable PCSs to a permanent national static or allied wide static 
core network infrastructure.

'''In contrast to deployable or mobile networks a static Protected Core Network requests a much higher level of redundancy, resilience, availability, performance and security.'''

At CWIX 2024 the first concepts, technologies and solutions had been 
successfully tested and delivered valuable input for STANAG, Service-Instruction
and testcases.

'''At CWIX 2025 existing standards and instructions will be validated, new input generated, technologies and solutions improved and more intensively tested in a multi-mission scenario with its specific but realistic challenges:'''

- '''Redundancy''' for PCN-1 connections based on policy-based routing, load sharing or load balancing

- '''Redundancy''' for vital services based on virtualization, clusters and containers

- '''Resilience''' by authentication, authorization, whitelisting and SLA policing

- '''Bandwidth''' management and control by implementation of QoS and SLA enforcement

- '''Seamless''' real-time monitoring the multi-mission PCN based on NMCD IES federations

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 4 for Tactical Edge
description: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 4 for Tactical Edge. Focus should be on CCs that plan to do SP4 testing outside of the JDSS domain. Limited interest may be expected, but for completeness use this objective.

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 5 for Tactical Edge
description: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 5 for Tactical Edge. CCs linked to this objective may perform tests related to SP5 waveforms, VARC based voice and simple multicast relaying.

name: Input for FMN Spiral 6+ for Tactical Edge
description: Input for FMN Spiral 6+ for Tactical Edge. This Objective gathers input from all CC's that plan to do SP6 testing for the tactical edge excluding JDSS. For example, tests related to waveforms, voice and data. Moreover, all input is gathered for testing relevant for SP7 and further.

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 4 for JDSSIN
description:
*Testing the implementations for FMN Spiral 4 (Land tactical C2 SI) for Joint Dismounted Soldiers System Interoperability Network JDSSIN according to STANAG 4677.
*The FMN4 AV&V test templates of last year will be used.
*Improving the test-templates and test-cases based on lessons learned from previous exercise.

name: Test Implementations for FMN Spiral 5 for JDSSIN
description:
*Testing the implementations for FMN Spiral 5 (Land tactical C2 SI) for Joint Dismounted Soldiers System Interoperability Network JDSSIN according to STANAG 4677.
*Improving the test-templates and test-cases based on lessons learned from previous exercise.

name: SCIP / Stac-IS
description:
Test SCIP and STaC-IS protocol interoperability and applicability for voice encryption but also for data over narrow band radios.

The Objective is open to exploration e.g. in the area of packet based STaC-IS/STaC-IS 2.0, experimentation e.g. regarding STaC-IS 1.1 and encapsulation techniques of stream based STaC-IS into RTP and examination of systems regarding stream based STaCIS.

name: NINE / NINE TP
description:
This objective focuses on interoperability testing and experimentation with encryption devices and implementations supporting the NATO Networking and Information Infrastructure (NII) Internet Protocol (IP) Network Encryptor – Interoperability Specification (NINE ISPEC), including the NINE Tactical Profile (NINE TP).


The primary purpose of NINE devices is to provide high assurance information confidentiality when transporting information between domains of trust. The NINE TP is a profile adapted for tactical encryption devices and encryption of IP communications in the Tactical Edge (TE).

The main focus of examination is regarding the NINE ISPEC while experimentation and exploration is performed within the NINE Tactical/Radio Profile.

name: ESSOR (European Secure Software Defined Radio)
description:
Multinational interoperability testing with the NATO ESSOR HDRWF (2023) (STANAG 5651 Ed 1) Waveform.

In this objective the participating capabilities will test the communication performance and interoperability of different national implementations of the aforementioned radio waveform on different national software defined radios.

name: Other Waveforms including 5G
description:
This objective will perform tests of various military Waveforms, such as SATURN (STANAG 4372 Ed.A) for LOS NB communication, STANAG 4606 ed 4 for Wideband Protected Satcom and ESSOR/GeoMux as well as other Waveforms including commercial ones like 5G for military application. 

In addition, Data Centric Security (DCS3-ACP240) will be explored on 5G environment with a Secure Over the Air delivery mechanism, allowing real time keys based on ABAC and labels distribution. This capability is performed on the FarEdge element with support of KAS to allow users to access to the encrypted data based on Labels. This capability allows the deployment of DCS3-ACP240 up to the last miles (terminals from private or even public network).

name: Consume, display and disseminate space data/space recognized picture
description: Examine and explore ways and means to consume, display and disseminate space data in the form of a recognized space picture or by other means of presentation (e.g. lists or charts)

name: Consume, display and disseminate cyber data/cyber recognized picture
description: Find and examine ways and means to receive, share and display Cyberspace data.

name: eXamine ADatP-36(A) 2 within the context of the standard
description: The objective of this test is to conduct a technical evaluation of ADatP-36(A)2, focusing on verifying compliance with Friendly Force Tracking (FFT) interoperability standards. The testing will validate the system’s capability to exchange FFT data accurately and efficiently, ensuring that it meets the technical requirements outlined in ADatP-36(A)2. Specific emphasis will be placed on assessing data formatting, transmission consistency, and integration across different C2 systems. The results of this test will provide insights for further refinement and standardization of FFT processes.

name: Testing ADatP-36(B) within the context of the standard
description: The objective of this test is to perform a technical evaluation of ADatP-36(B), focusing on the advanced requirements for Friendly Force Tracking (FFT) interoperability. The testing will assess the system’s ability to implement the new features and data exchange protocols specified in ADatP-36(B), ensuring compliance with updated standards. Particular attention will be given to the enhanced data handling capabilities, security features, and compatibility with other systems. The results will contribute to the overall understanding and improvement of interoperability within multinational operational environments.

name: eXamine ADatP-36(A) 2 within the context of the standard on Green
description: Test ADatP-36, non FMN AV&V related. Objective for CC's on the unclassified enclave

name: Pre-Testing for FFT Comprehensive SCENARIO eXamination
description:
The Pre-Testing phase is mandatory for all participants involved in the FFT Scenario. Pre-testing's primary purpose is to perform an early, thorough evaluation of each participant's system capabilities, configurations, and interoperability readiness. During Pre-Testing, systems are assessed to ensure they can correctly exchange data across different networks, protocols, and mediation services as required by the scenario.

This phase aims to identify and mitigate technical or configuration issues before the execution of the main scenario, thus minimizing risks, avoiding delays, and ensuring a smoother and more effective testing campaign. The Pre-Tests cover connectivity verification, data format compatibility, protocol adherence (such as ADatP-36(A)(2), ADatP-36(B), CoT, JDSS 1.1 and JDSS 1.2 standards), and initial cross-domain data exchange simulations when applicable.

Successful completion of Pre-Testing is a prerequisite for participation in the full FFT Scenario, ensuring that only systems meeting the required baseline level of interoperability proceed to the comprehensive evaluation phase.

name: Test the concept of Day 0 interoperability
description:
Test the concept of Day 0 interoperability, including incident recovery (hub/proxy failure)

Following the FMN Spiral 4 instructions:

For the Network Management Authority Role (NMA):
* the Network Management Authority will create the FFT network Configuration and will publish it for all the participant capabilities

For Participant capabilities:
* Participants will configure their FFT systems directly by reading the configuration information from the FFT network Configuration message received from the NMA with only minor or no human intervention

Additional for Spiral 5 and ADatP36-(B), functionality to test is:
*Including the automated configuration message. Explore the automated machine interpretation and generation of the FMN Service Instruction document.

name: eXamine cross security domain exchange of Friendly Force Tracks
description: The objective of this test is to evaluate the cross-security domain exchange of Friendly Force Tracks (FFT) data to ensure seamless information flow between networks of different security classifications. The test will focus on verifying the accuracy, security, and reliability of FFT data transmitted between classified and unclassified domains. Special attention will be given to ensuring compliance with security protocols to prevent unauthorized access and maintain data integrity during transmission. The outcome will help validate the system's ability to provide accurate situational awareness across multiple security environments.

name: eXamine the usability of AdatP-37 (Ground to Air Info Exchange)
description: Services to forward Friendly Force Information to Weapon Delivery Assets within a coalition network or a federation of networks over Link 16. The goal of this objective is to evaluate the implementation of ADatP-37 within C2 (Command and Control) systems, specifically focusing on their ability to forward Friendly Force Information to weapon delivery assets. This includes verifying how situational awareness (SA) information is transmitted from NATO Force Tracking Systems (FTS), C2 systems, and Combat Identification (CID) systems to tactical units, utilizing tactical data links. The test will assess whether these C2 systems adhere to the standardized principles for reducing the risk of fratricide and collateral damage. The outcomes will provide insight into the effectiveness of information flow between identification systems and attack-associated units in the NATO operational environment.

name: To extend FFT to the Tactical Edge using Cursor on Target [TAK]
description: The objective of this test is to evaluate the ability to effectively extend Friendly Force Tracking (FFT) capabilities to the Tactical Edge by utilizing Cursor on Target (CoT) protocols, specifically through the TAK (Tactical Assault Kit) suite. This involves assessing how well FFT data can be integrated and disseminated in environments that rely on lightweight, mobile, and often disconnected nodes. The test will also focus on the mediation between Friendly Force Information (FFI) and Cursor on Target (CoT) data standards, ensuring that data can be seamlessly and reliably translated between these different formats to maintain situational awareness. The evaluation will include testing data accuracy, consistency, and the ability to handle synchronization between FFI and CoT standards under various operational conditions. The goal is to ensure that all tactical units at the edge of the network receive timely and accurate information to support decision-making and reduce operational risks.

name: To extend FFT to the Tactical Edge using Cursor on Target
description: The objective of this test is to evaluate the ability to effectively extend Friendly Force Tracking (FFT) capabilities to the Tactical Edge by utilizing Cursor on Target (CoT) protocols, specifically through the TAK (Tactical Assault Kit) suite. This involves assessing how well FFT data can be integrated and disseminated in environments that rely on lightweight, mobile, and often disconnected nodes. The test will also focus on the mediation between Friendly Force Information (FFI) and Cursor on Target (CoT) data standards, ensuring that data can be seamlessly and reliably translated between these different formats to maintain situational awareness. The evaluation will include testing data accuracy, consistency, and the ability to handle synchronization between FFI and CoT standards under various operational conditions. The goal is to ensure that all tactical units at the edge of the network receive timely and accurate information to support decision-making and reduce operational risks.

name: To extend FFT to the Tactical Edge using JDSS
description:
Experimenting FMN Spiral 6 Specifications and systems implementation maturity with respect to the 'vertical' exchange/mediation of information between OPCIS and TACCIS.

The following FMN Spiral 6 Specifications are eXperimented: 
* [https://tide.act.nato.int/mediawiki/fmn6/index.php/Procedural_Instructions_for_C2_of_Land_Operations Procedural Instruction for C2 of Land Operations]
* [https://tide.act.nato.int/mediawiki/fmnroadmap25/index.php/Service_Instructions_for_Land_Tactical_C2_Information_Exchange Service Instruction(s) for Land Tactical C2 Information Exchange]

This Objective covers the following FMN Spiral 6 Capability Enhancements (CPEs):

* [https://tide.act.nato.int/mediawiki/fmnroadmap25/index.php/CPE-633 CPE-633]: Define the technical implementation of automatic Friendly Force Tracks (FFT) exchange between OPCIS and TACCIS.
* [https://tide.act.nato.int/mediawiki/fmnroadmap25/index.php/CPE-205 CPE-205]: Update Land C2 Message Information profile for the tactical domain.

And the following Technology Interaction (TIN):

Including the Profile (PRF):

In support of the exchange of the following Data Objects (DOBs):

* [https://tide.act.nato.int/mediawiki/fmn6/index.php?title=DOB-113 DOB-113]: JDSSDM 1.2 Presence Message Extension.

name: FFT Comprehensive SCENARIO eXamination
description:
Comprehensive in this objective refers to the thorough and all-encompassing evaluation of the FFT scenario, ensuring that every aspect of the system's performance, interoperability, and operational capabilities are tested. This includes testing various communication protocols, data exchanges, system configurations, and network interactions across different environments and security domains. The goal is to identify any potential challenges, verify system readiness, and ensure the seamless integration of the FFT systems within the broader operational context.
The goals of the Objectives are:
* to design and execute system's interoperability testing scheme / scenario to ensure that different systems can seamlessly exchange FFT data related to friendly force tracking without any compatibility issues.
* to focuses more on the ability to transfer tactical-level data, regardless of the format or the standard on which the data is based. The emphasis here is on operational needs, where we use mediation services to convert the data from one format to another.
* to design Scenario to cover four different test groups, each of which focuses on a specific aspect of interoperability: 
#Scenario Execution Test Group: This group of tests verifies the interoperability of systems in the PINK Network and GREEN Unclass (Unclassified) networks. The tests focus on consolidating the systems within the networks to ensure seamless exchange of FFT data between them. This process is in accordance with the ADatP-36(A)(2) standard for FMN Spiral 4 (SP4) and ADatP-36(B) standard for FMN Spiral 5 (SP5), ensuring compatibility and smooth data flow.
#Cross Security Domain Exchange Test Group: This group of tests verifies the interoperability of systems that exchange FFT data across different security domains. The tests focus on the exchange of DCS (Distributed Common Ground System) and FFT data, ensuring that the data is securely transferred between the domains. Due to accreditation limitations (e.g., data guard/data diode), real tests between different security domains may not be feasible. The testing will likely take place in a simulated environment
#CoT (Cursor on Target) Test Group: This group of tests verifies the interoperability of systems that exchange FFT data using the CoT mediation services. The focus is on testing the CoT protocol and ensuring proper interoperability between the CoT and FFT systems.
#JDSS (Joint Dismounted Soldier Systems) Test Group: This group of tests verifies the interoperability of systems that use JDSS to display the positions of their own units. The Scenario tests focus on ensuring that the JDSS systems can accurately and seamlessly exchange data with FFT systems, ensuring interoperability and integration between these systems for improved situational awareness regarding the positions of their own forces. The test part includes an examination in alignment with FMN SP5.

name: Maritime Land Integration in a realistic Operational scenario (eXamine)
description:
This objective looks to exercise an exchange of RGP and RMP between the land and maritime domain. The exchange of data includes tracks and overlays for situational awareness. Targeting quality tracks will not fall into the scope of this objective. The three primary protocols used to achieve the exchange will be OTH, NVG, FFT, and MIP. Other protocols may be used where required. Each land CC will connect to the NCIA MCCIS or another maritime CC.

A separate test case should be made for tracks and overlays.

The secondary subtask is to ascertain whether or not the testing done at CWIX can be replicated on operational networks, such as VEVA or other NATO Secret networks.

Expected maturity of systems should be fielded or near fielded.

name: Air Land Integration in a realistic Operational scenario
description:
Test Air Land Integration through information exchange and link forwarding.

Examine and Exercise the functionality, performance, and interoperability of Air and Land systems under realistic operational conditions. The goal is to ensure that information is shared accurately and promptly between air & land focus areas (simulating a JAGIC/ASOC cell interacting with higher Air & Land tactical echelons - i.e ASOC -> CAOC COD floor)

Examine:
1) Communication Systems
TDLs: Examine the compatibility and reliability between the various TDL systems and other AIRC2 Federated Systems (Real & Non Real Time)

2) Interoperability:
Platform Integration: Examine if Air & Land systems can exchange data seamlessly.
Protocol Compatibility: Examine that all systems used NATO compatible data formats and protocols.

3) Information Accuracy
Sensors: Examine if simulated sensor data (e.g., target coordinates) is transferred between LAND & AIRC2 systems in an correct & accurate way.
Data Fusion: Examine the accuracy of fused data from multiple sources, including ASM,TGTs, Friendly positions, etc...

4) Situational Awareness // Decision Support 
Shared Picture: Examine if an accurate common operational picture (COP) across Air & Land Domains is created

Exercise:
Exercise in order to verify the consistency, resiliency and accuracy of the information shared between Air & Land domains (at different echelons & real time/non real time) in a representative operational scenario. 
This will help determine accuracy (percentage of correctly transmitted information) and level of Interoperability (number of successful system integrations) in a real world scenario.

name: eXplore opportunities for Space and Cyber Integration
description: TBC

name: Aggregate RGP between NATO and National LAND Capabilities (eXamine & eXercise)
description: Aggregate RGP between NATO and National LAND Capabilities. National LAND C2 Capabilities have the possibility to assess the level of interoperability with NATO C2 Capabilities, based on FMN Spiral 3 and 4 LC2IS service functions within an operational scenario. Moreover, testing against different Nato Vector Graphics implementation could be achieved in other to clarify a sustainable RP.

name: Exchange BSOs between National Capabilities (eXercise)
description: eXercise. Exchange Battle Space Objects (BSOs) between National Capabilities To asses the interoperability among National LAND Capabilities based on FMN Spiral 3 LC2IES service functions.

name: Provide RGP to MDO C2 from collated MCLCCs (eXercise)
description: eXercise. Provide RGP to MDC2 from collated from MCLCC units. MCLCCs will collate RGPs from Corps and provide JOA RGPs to MDC2.

name: Consume COP from MDC2 and disseminate to subordinates
description: The aim of the OBJ is to eXamine consuming the COP (assume NCOP) generated by MDC2 at the lowest tactical level (assume MCLCC or Corps)

name: eXperiment and eXamine CBRN information exchange between National CBRN systems and with C2 systems
description: Experimentation and Examination on CBRN data exchange between partner systems in the multidomain command & control environment.  Point to point data exchange among CBRN-specific systems will aid in validating conformance of CBRN report format and content adherence to established ADatP-03 standards.  Promulgation from CBRN systems into C2 systems will validate the functionality of the CBRN information.  Promulgation from CBRN systems into NCDF Data Lake will enable broader applicability and socialization of the CBRN information beyond the Land FA and among multiple capability sets and information systems in multidomain operations.

name: eXercise multi-national targeting/fires interoperability
description:
This objective is intended to examine fielded and near fielded multi-national Fires/Targeting interoperability in order to validate the standards developed in Artillery Systems Cooperation Activities (ASCA). Exercise parameters will validate National Interface Operating Procedures (NIOP) between Nations within in the guide of the scenario developed within the Land Focus Area. National Fires/ Targeting systems will provide a Fires Common Operating Picture (COP) to be incorporated into the overall LAND FA COP. Nations will operate as different echelons of organizations and will be required to contribute and incorporate the MCLCC fires/targeting guidance's, as well as submitting targets for executions to lower and higher echelon forces for action. 

Expectation of systems/ CCs will be fielded or near-fielded, operating within the FMN Spiral 4 on the Pink enclave.  

The Land FA scenario will examine the ability of the systems/ CCs within the object to meet the following standards are required for ASCA V.07 and will be exercised / validated between ASCA membered Nations:

AFU.AMS	        (Artillery Fire Unit – Ammunition Status)
AFU.FUS 	(Artillery Fire Unit – Fire Unit Status)
AFU.GUS	        (Artillery Fire Unit – General Unit Status)
AFU.DCMD	(Artillery Fire Unit – Deployment Command)
AFU.RDO	        (Artillery Fire Unit – Radar Deployment Order)
AFU.TAUS	(Artillery Fire Unit – Target Acquisition Unit Status)
ATI.ATR		(Artillery Target Intelligence – Artillery Target Report)
FM.CFF		(Fire Mission – Call for Fire)
FM.EOM		(Fire Mission – End of Mission)
FM.FMC		(Fire Mission – Fire Mission Command)
FM.SUB		(Fire Mission – Subsequent Adjustment)
FM.MTO		(Fire Mission – Message to Observer)
MET.CM		(Meteorological – Computer)
SPRT.ACM	(Support – Airspace Coordination Measures)
SPRT.GEOM	(Support – Battlefield Geometry)
SYS.RRM	        (System – Reply or Remarks Message)

With nations not able to currently operating ASCA V.07 they will be aligned with nations that systems that are backwards compatible, and will utilize NIOPs established by the ASCA community. Nations not having full membership into ASCA and nations wanting to conduct testing will explore interoperability based on the above standards.

name: Forward Land Forces Interoperability for Host and Framework Nations (eXercise)
description: eXercise Forward Land Forces Interoperability for Host and Framework Nations

name: Test Standards for interoperability between NATO and National C2/C3 Systems and Simulations
description: This is the venue for testing the ability of Simulation Systems to stimulate and be stimulated by NATO and National C2/C3 Systems. Different M&S systems will send/receive tracks to/from NATO and National C2/C3 systems through different protocols.

name: Incorporate Expert System information within M&S Federation
description: Expert Systems need to be incorporated within complex M&S architectures in order to provide reliable high value technical information, related to effects determined by different types of operational environment (Electro-Magnetic Spectrum Operations - EMSO, Chemical Biological Radiological, Nuclear - CBRN). This objective has been put in place to test the integration of information determined by existing Expert Systems projects using NETN (NATO Education and Training Network) FOM (Federation Object Model), so that these systems are able to share information with Computer Generated Forces tools.

name: Test Standards for interoperability between NATO and National C2/C3 Systems and Simulations
description: This is the venue for testing the ability of Simulation Systems to stimulate and be stimulated by NATO and National C2/C3 Systems. Use cases will be based within the context of Mission Rehearsal and Collective Training & Exercises.  (If you plan to test non-Simulation source against C2/C3, please consider to use different objective.)

name: Audacious Wargaming assisted by SIM ( Educational Computer Assisted Wargaming – EdCAW)
description:
Educational Computer-assisted wargaming (EdCAW) simulates warfighting incidents using a constructive simulation system. We will conduct a distributed EdCAW using two JCATS of different versions in a federation.

The exploration of simulated results from every federated system aims to explore the quality of the federated interactions. The produced analytical reports will also be explored. This Objective deals with the federation of simulation systems, which is a topic of SPIRAL 7. It will explore federated interactions between the main domains (Land, maritime, and Air), collecting the necessary simulated results.

name: eXplore and test M&S Emerging and Disruptive Technologies (EDTs)
description: These are those new and innovative technologies that, while emerging, also bring disruption and a new layer of complexity to our Warfare Domains. Examples are Artificial Intelligence (AI), Autonomous Systems, Data Exploitation, Digital Twins and Extended Reality (XR).

name: Explore SIM-SIM interoperability requirements in the context of MR and CTE
description: Explore Simulation - Simulation interoperability requirements in the context of Mission Rehearsel and Collective Training and Exercises. Expected outcomes are: confirmation of compliance with the HLA specification for sim-sim interoperation according to STANAG 4603) and with the relevant modules of the Federation Object Model specified in AMSP-04 (STANREC 4800 Ed 2).

name: Explore SMC and security interoperability requirements in the support of MR and CTE
description:
1. Explore existing capabilities for managing generic cloud hosted simulation services and federated simulation systems 

2. Discover requirements for Service Management and Control and Security of cloud hosted simulation services.

name: eXpl and eXpe - Advance NATO Space Domain Interop with Space tools - PINK
description: NATO started implementing the Space Domain and part of the effort is to follow the CFCDGM (Combined Funded Capability Delivery Governance Model) to develop a Space Domain Tool capable of providing awareness, sharing data and products and providing planners and decision makers the right information pertaining to Space for joint planning and execution of activities, missions and operations.

name: Advance NATO Space Domain Interop with Space tools (Space) (MDO/DT)
description: NATO started implementing the Space Domain and part of the effort is to follow the CFCDGM to develop a Space Domain Tool capable of providing awareness, sharing data and products and providing planners and decision makers the right information pertaining to Space for joint planning and execution of activities, missions and operations.

name: eXpl and eXpe - Raise Space Awareness within NATO
description: NATO Space Domain Awareness (SDA) function is the common understanding, comprehension and perception of all aspects associated with the Space Domain, to include threats and vulnerabilities which could impact NATO and Allies' safety, security, economy and environment. SDA encompasses the Seven Functional Areas: Space Situational Awareness (SSA), Intelligence, Surveillance, Reconnaissance (ISR), Meteorology & Oceanography (METOC), Satellite Communication (SATCOM), Positioning, Navigation, Timing (PNT), Shared Early Warning (SEW)

name: Experiment with AI and KM support for orchestrating dynamic MD effects
description:
Overview: Air and ground forces conduct precision strikes on key adversary positions. Cyber disrupts adversary C3 systems and contribute with offensive cyber operation. Information operations and stratcom supports the strategic and operational mission. Dynamic time-sensitive targeting (TST) is included to address pop-up targets within 30 min.

Background:
 - AIMED is an immature add-on to the very mature SitaWare HQ.
 - For AI to be trustworthy, the data going in must be continuously validated by SMEs.  AIMED will implement a simplified workflow that fits with general C2 operations and enables each warfighting function in each operations centre to continuously validate the data and connections between relevant data elements (i.e., information).
 - Operationalized KM will be a combination of fit-for-purpose user interfaces and automated message handling data associations built into AIMED.

Operational sketch:
 1. Collect & manage SA (SA KM):
   - recognized domain pictures
   - task organizations
   - unit readiness & loadout status
   - Joint Prioritized Target List
   - weather & terrain
   - execution matrix (BPT tasks)
 2. MDOC/AIMED receive and parse Call For Fire message from LANDCOM
 3. AI generate options based on platform status & location
 4. Collaboratively agree on option (MD workflow KM)

name: To Exchange and process Non MTF data (Air)
description:
OVERVIEW: 
Interoperability is the capacity for 2 or more entities to share and exchange data and information so that those entities can operate coherently, effectively and efficiently together to achieve Alliance objectives. In order to test interoperability, it is required that the AIR C2 system architecture in NATO as well as in national systems is compliant with the standards. Interoperability between AIRC2 System is of paramount importance to the execution of NATO mission. 

BACKGROUND:
The testing phase will check the interoperability of the AIRC2 System in the Non Real Time domain concerning NON MTF (Messages Text Format) messages. Therefore it will tested the correct exchange, ingestion and process of Non MTF messages such as:
-Order of battle
-Resource List
-Frequency Plan
-PTL
-PDAL
-C2 Plan
-Unit
-Airbases
-Aircraft

- EXERCISE will commit fielded CCs to test and consolidate their interoperability in exchanging operational messages and information and process them. A simulated scenario, test cases and joint vignette will be used.  

- EXAMINATION will commit fielded and soon-fielded CCs to eXamine their interoperability and generate an Interoperability Matrix. 

- EXPERIMENTATION will commit soon-fielded CCs to confirm their interoperability with other systems by exchanging all/some of the above mentioned messages.

name: To exchange and process MTF messages
description:
The overall intent is to test the dissemination of MTF messages between CC:
- at JFAC level (operational units) - JFAC, CAOC,..
- and at ARS level and below (Tactical&subtactical units) - CRC, ARS, WOC,...

The testing phases will consist of processing MTF (Message Text Format) Messages (eg. ATO, ACO) using ADatP-3 formats by:
- creating - if applicable - the various products using the respective CC tools.
- disseminating them to relevant CC (JFAC to ARS or vice-versa if applicable)
- implementing the received products into the CC and make sure they are integer and usable.

These steps will be provided in a specific scenario - test cases

- "Examination" will commit fielded and soon-fielded CC to elaborate -fully or at least partially - an IO matrix between "JFAC" CC and "ARS" CC.

- "Exercise" will commit fielded CC to consolidate the exchange processes in regards with respective Standards implementation/updates.

name: To exchange real time messages over TDL
description:
Surveillance and control of the airspace requires ability to exchange and to process data received via a TDL network.

NATO and national AirC2 systems under test, both fielded and near fielded, must be able to produce, disseminate and/or compile a Recognized Air Picture (RAP) and or Common Operational Picture (COP) contributing to situational awareness from platform to joint level.

Capability of the systems to distribute, receive and process TDL based information/data will be tested.

Objective primary focus is exercising data exchange via L16, L22 and/or JREAP-C.
Secondary objective focus is to examine data exchange Data exchange between different information domains via overlay distribution (i.e, assessing the relations between NVG and TDL messages)

name: To exchange BMD air specific messages
description:
AirC2 systems must be able to process BMD messages (J3.0,J3.6, SEW/SEW+) IOT ensure the capability to participate to the global coverage of the battlefield.
CC in any Maturity level can join this objective. 

- Experimentation: CC are encouraged to test with developmental capabilities that will be processing Space Tracks (J3.0,J3.6 ) or Shared Early Warnings (SWE) messages.

- Examination: CC will examine how the respective Fielded or near fielded C2 system process Space Tracks (BMD) and resolve possible interoperability issues.

name: V&V of FMN spiral 4 for maritime related services

V&V of FMN spiral 4 for maritime related services (MDO)
- Conformance Testing
- De-risking Coalition Operations
