name: To exchange AirC2 information via webservices
description:
To connect to, receive and process Air C2 information (Examples being the ORBAT, ACO, ACM, ATO, NOTAM, ACMREQ data types) via webservices. Participants should upload their respective [[ICD_(acronym)|ICDs]] concerning their webservice capabilities in order that other capabilities can code towards that interface in the [[DC-063|document container]].
Standards may be added based on participating capabilities [[STD-01215|SOAP]], REST services etc.

Experimentation scope is dedicated for CCs which do not currently (fully) implement/support a certain interface, but are interested in becoming interoperable in the future.

Examination scope is for CCs that are already interconnectable via the specific ICDs and want to validate their implementation.

The format of the data exchanged via webservices can be proprietary and does not necessarily follow a certain MTF standard. For MTF exchange, use [[OBJ-116]].

name: Test MDO tactical capabilities contribution to air situational awareness
description: When combining assets (Air and other domains) on a tactical level an AirC2 system must be able to receive and process MDO relevant data to produce a Recognized Air Picture (RAP) and facilitate local air situational awareness

name: Real-Time Interoperability test with national and NATO C2 Systems
description: To test interoperability with different C2 systems via L16 JREAP : - Exchange of air picture - Command and engage orders - Exchange of space picture

name: Air to Maritime integration
description:
Air/Ground/Surface platforms integration through information exchange. 
*The primary aim of this examination is to evaluate and validate the effectiveness and interoperability of the RMP and Common Operational Picture (COP) dissemination in a multidomain environment. This involves assessing the readiness and capability of assigned C2 systems in integrating and disseminating air and maritime operational data, including air-to-maritime information exchange using APP-11 standards.
**Assess the ability to seamlessly incorporate air and maritime operational data within the COP.
**Ensure that situational awareness is maintained across all operational forces.
**Validate the use of APP-11 standards to enhance interoperability between air and maritime units.
*The aim of this exercise is to ensuring seamless integration of air and maritime operational data. The exercise will focus on:
**Assessing the ability to incorporate air and maritime operational data within the COP to maintain a synchronized and accurate operational picture.
**Ensuring situational awareness across all operational forces, enabling effective decision-making and coordination in real-time.
**Validating the use of APP-11 standards to enhance interoperability between air and maritime units, ensuring standardized and efficient information exchange.

name: LEFCIS
description:
Test interoperability of the LEFCIS  (Link Encryption Family Cryptographic Interoperability Specification) (up to V3.4  - so earlier LEFCIS versions are also welcome..).
Note that LEFCIS is currently a joint UK-US specification, and has been put forward to become a NATO Standard (STANAG) by those 2 Nations at the Network & Security (N&S) CaT . To be evaluated by the N&S Cat by end-24, and if deemed appropriate a standardisation proposal will be submitted.

Suite-B AES implementation between different Crypto Producing Nations (CPNs).
This profile will be used for the Ship-Shore, MRL (BRASS & BRIPES) & intra-TG working. 

There are several CPNs who should be testing interoperability (in parenthesis the devices):
UK (BID 2510/18), US (KIV-7M), ITA (CM 109M), TUR (MILON 4-M), DEU (ELCRODAT 7MC

As a second step is to prove interoperability over ‘real HF channel conditions’ – i.e. an HF ‘channel simulator’ to simulate the channel between the cryptos , to make the test more representative of the ‘real life environment’ . OBJ-10 in Maritime FA : C2D2E testing is proposing such a simulator, so there can be synergies with that objective.

As a third step, is to test end-to-end the actual applications that are going to be utilized over LEFCIS – i.e. formal messaging/email/chat over STANAG 5066 /the BRIPES protocol stack (CC-041)

name: Loaned Radio tests of JDSSIN for FMN
description:
Loaned Radio tests for FMN Spiral 4/5 (Land tactical C2 SI) for Joint Dismounted Soldiers System Interoperability Network JDSSIN according to STANAG 4677.Typically the tests were splitted into a connection test and the exchange of the situational awarness with e.g. Friendly Force Tracking and Tactical Data. 

Two different setups can be used:
* Loaned Radio is connected via JDSS Connector (Soldier)
* Loaned Radio is connected via LAN RJ45 Connector (e.g. Vehicle) The LAN Tests can be performed with an arbitrary set of two IP Radios.

Your CC provides a radio link (e.g. PRC-117, ESSOR, 5G, national radio).
You want to test your radio link with Soldier or Vehicle Systems?
You are invited for testing.

The JDSS System are mobile and could come to your CC with the radio link setup.

name: New NATO Force Model (NFM, eFP, ARF, …)
description:
Test coalition interoperability in the context of the new NATO Force Model, including fielded and near-fielded systems, e.g. eFP and VJTF (Very High Readiness Joint Task Forces).

NATO Force Model like eFP and VJTF often require specialized short and midterm solutions for communication. On the other hand, the systems should be aligned as much as possible to the FMN architecture.

Concrete tests will include solutions for coalition defence in all NATO joint operation areas (JOA).

name: MED C2 and Reporting (on NU)
description:
This objective covers medical command and control (C2) processes on green, including but not limited to patient tracking, patient regulating, and syndromic surveillance, and all relevant data exchanges. This is enabled by the following messaging, and in this order:

[1] Examine units sending 9-liners up to the patient evacuation coordination cell (PECC)

[2] Examine medical treatment facilities (MTFs) sending patient tracking messages (PTMs) up to the PECC to report patient admissions, department transfer and discharges

[3] Examine the PECC sending PTMs down to the MTFs to provide updates on transports having departed, being in-progress and having arrived

[4] Examine MTFs sending patient movement requests (PMRs) and bulk PMRs up to the PECC

And furthermore:

[5] Experiment with MTFs sending SENSOR messages up to the health surveillance center

name: MED C2 and Reporting (on Pink)
description:
This objective covers medical command and control (C2) processes on pink, including but not limited to medical reporting. This is enabled by:

[1] Explore medical C2 data that is captured on green to be pushed to pink through a diode

[2] Examine the exposing of medical data layers, for example containing the locations and status of MTFs, to be consumed by situational awareness (SA)/common operational picture (COP) capabilities

name: MIP4-IES - FFT Cross-CoI Interoperability (REST)
description:
This objective goal is to explore the interactions between MIP systems and FFT systems. The main interaction is that the MIP system can provide the augmented information which can be combined by a situation awareness (SI) system to augment the received blue dot tracks.

The business process which enables this, is described in the FMN instructions for FFT in section X.

The format used for the augmentation file is mentioned in the SI and is described in detail in ADatP36 B.

General test template:

Producer: an producing participant has one or more Systems. These systems fulfil the following rules:

FFT Gateway, representing one or more FFT terminals
MIP provider
Asset database or Orbat
Mediator: a MIP system that can produce an augmentation file.

Receiver: an SA system which has an FFT receiver capability and FFT augmenting capability

An FFT producer has an MIP interface and provides orbat/bso information to the MIP system. Or it is provided by a third system with the transponder id's assigned to its FFT terminals. This third system has also an MIP interface and provides orbat/bso information to the MIP system.
The MIP system generates a task order. The Task order is converted to a augmentation file.
The Augmentation file is used by all FFT receivers
The FFT producer is sending 🔵
A FFT receiver is receiving 🔵 and augments it with augmentation file and displays a proper track in line with the track as is known by the Producer.

name: Provide coherent RAP to Joint Level
description:
NATO and national AirC2 systems, both fielded and near fielded, must be able to produce and disseminate Recognized Air Picture (RAP) contributing to the joint situational awareness.

Providing a coherent Recognized Air Picture (RAP) to the joint level means integrating and presenting a unified and accurate situational awareness picture of all air activity relevant to a specific area of responsibility or operation. This picture supports decision-making and operations in a joint operations context by integrating also land, maritime, and space components . The goal is to ensure a clear, shared understanding of the multi domain environment of a military force, enabling seamless coordination and effective mission execution.

To provide a coherent RAP to the joint level, the following steps are typically involved:
1.	Sensor Integration and Data Collection
	• Collect data from diverse sensors such as ground-based radars, airborne warning and control systems (AWACS), naval radar systems, and space-based sensors (simulated, if available).
	• Ensure that data from all available platforms (land, maritime, and space) is transmitted in real-time or near-real-time.
2.	Data Fusion and Processing
	• Use advanced data fusion algorithms and systems to combine raw data from multiple sources, removing duplicates and resolving ambiguities.
	• Process the data into a common format that is accessible and understandable to all components of the joint force.
3.	Collaboration Across Domains
	• Establish joint coordination centers or nodes where representatives from land, maritime, and space components collaborate to verify, validate, and refine the RAP.
	• Use shared decision-support tools to allow for cross-domain input and updates in real time.
4.	Command and Control (C2) Integration
	• Integrate RAP into existing joint command and control systems to provide commanders with a Comprehensive Operational Picture.
	• Ensure that RAP is linked to other domain-specific recognized pictures (e.g., Recognized Maritime Picture, Recognized Space Picture) for holistic situational awareness.
5.	Continuous Monitoring and Validation
	• Continuously monitor the airspace and validate the RAP against real-world observations and intelligence to maintain accuracy.
	•

name: Deployment and Sustainment Management
description:
The deployment and sustainment management objective is a miscellaneous catch-all bucket for small packets or isolated instances of logistics test cases that do not merit a test objective in their own right.

The following elements are planned under the deployment and sustainment management objective in the Unclassified Standalone and Green enclaves:

* Explore and experiment with the development of  digital solutions that support comprehensive, secure and assured multi-party transit documentation information exchanges necessary for the streamlined cross-border movement of military goods for NATO forces. See [[CC-404]], EST SDMMS 1, which manages military movement requests, and national systems [[CC-259]], [[CC-219]] and [[CC-374]] that manage information related to the transport assets involved in a movement.

* Experiment with the NATO information system LOGFAS, identifying options for potential development. This will involve attempts to automate the import, enriching and transfer of  deployment and sustainment data and to move the resulting product across security domains using different methods. 

* Experimenting with possible solutions to MED transport requests. If successful, the medical movement data will be made visible in one or more common operational pictures via LOGFAS.

* Examining the latest version 10 release of LOGFAS to verify and validate the continued ability for TOPFAS-exported data to be imported by LOGFAS. This is a precursor to some logistics instructions being agreed under FMN Spiral 6 later in 2025. LOGFAS trials in CWIX25 will not attempt to validate those, at present, draft and unfinished instructions.

* Experiment with the data integration and exchange of Finnish KULTI transportation management capability information [[CC-273]] with FIN LOGFAS system [[CC-259]].

Capabilities participating in testing are drawn from across the system lifecycle: developmental, experimental and fielded.

name: Extension and evolution of a collaborative digital manufacturing environment
description:
Additive Manufacturing (AM), more popularly called 3D printing, is the process of creating a 3D solid object, layer by layer, from a digital model. NATO sees it as an emerging and disruptive technology with the potential to improve readiness, reduce obsolescence issues, decrease sustainment costs, compress the supply chain, and enhance warfighting capability. It is generally believed that AM and, more generally, advanced manufacturing will lead to the digitalization of production and freedom of design and will be widely adopted in the medium term.

While this objective’s focus is on AM, enabling AM requires considering many other factors besides the actual printing. Furthermore, the digital creation of the technical data package (TDP) and data preparation is just as important as the actual printing. Hence, the referencing to advanced- and digital manufacturing. Additionally, a broader referencing also highlight that AM is just another tool in the manufacturing process or supply chain that nations can exploit to solve their issue.

Concerning AM, this objective divide AM into three broad categories, (i) pre-processing, (ii) manufacturing (i.e., the printing), and (iii) post-processing. These three categories are elaborated below, however, is by no means exhausted.

(i) Pre-processing includes creating the TDP and data preparation. This involves multiple steps of which multiple options arise within those steps. For example, design for AM (DfAM) is achievable by reverse engineer the part from 3D scanning or building the 3D model from scratch using Computer Aided Design (CAD) software. The TDP must contain all relevant information for printing the part as well as all the post-processing requirement and specifications. 

(ii) Manufacturing includes the seven main AM technologies and it’s various sub-categories. The seven AM technologies are: Material extrusion (MEX), Vat photopolymerization (VPP), Powder bed fusion (PBF), Binder jetting (BJT), Material jetting (MJT), Directed energy deposition (DED), and Sheet lamination (SHL).

(iii) Post-processing includes the necessary processes from other manufacturing technologies and inputs to finalize the printed part such as, but not limited to, Computed Numerical Control (CNC) milling, sintering, grinding, polishing, painting, and assembling.

Quality assurance (QA) throughout these three categories are in many instances mandatory and increases the likelihood of a functional end-use part. Furthermore, these three categories are intertwined with governance and life cycle management (LCM). Governance and LCM includes topics like legislations, business agreements, development of standards, development of QA processes, technology development, file sharing, cyber security, and much more.

This objective aims to: 

•	Explore some of the requirement for an “AM TDP” that that encompass data preparation alongside specifications and requirements for raw material, printer/machine settings, utilities, and environmental factors in every necessary step of pre-processing, manufacturing, and post-processing processes (e.g., first Wire Arc AM (WAAM) printing, second CNC milling, third Hot Isostatic Pressure (HIP) sintering).

•	Exploring and experiment aspects of the required digital thread for enabling the “AM TDP” in a deployed micro factory alongside exploring the possibilities of enabling digital QA in the digital manufacturing environment (starting with the AM printing processes).

•	Experiment aspects of national instances NATO’s digital library, RAPiD-e, in the Green enclave.

•	Explore and experiment various governance and LCM initial requirements for initiatives such as:

o	Aspects of intellectual property rights (IPR) protection for original equipment manufactures (OEM) and suppliers through serial numbers and markings.

o	Aspects of customs, exports licenses’, and dual use TDPs and digital files transferring across boarders and between commercial- and governmental entities. 

o	Aspects of feedback loop between customer and supplier to ensure safekeeping of IPR, monetization, and QA for warranty and liability.

o	Aspects of training and educational initiatives to increase "AM literacy" throughout the entire AM cycle from strategical business development and contractual agreement to the technical capabilities to DfAM and operate the printer.

•	Explore some of the options and requirements for enabling "AM situational awareness" at both national and NATO level. This includes locations of availability within the three broad categories such as reverse engineering capabilities, print capacity (alongside which types of raw material), and after treatment options.

This objective aims to both advance AM in general as well as tie CWIX into similar NATO AM initiatives and exercises such as the Applied Vehicle Technologies’ (AVT) new exploratory team (ET), AVT-ET-254, under NATO’s Science and Technology Organization (STO) and the 2025 asset tracking exercise Asset Tracking Capability Integration Campaign (ATCIC). Furthermore, when applicable, the aim is to also tie CWIX into AM initiatives beyond NATO such as European Defence Fund projects, European Defence Agency’s AM Village and Additive Manufacturing for Logistics Support (AMLS), and Multinational Logistics Coordination Center’s (MLCC) Capable Logistician 27 (CL27).

name: Novel Technology & Software in Medical Support
description:
Integrate new software solutions and technology in a multinational context to enhance the capture, collation, and exchange of both medical data and medical C2 data.

The types of messages to exchange include:

*Electronic Treatment Record 
*Patient Transfer Message
*TAK Messaging Position Location Information

Goals: 

1. Experiment with the Zafe capability to act as a portable server for OpMed CDP and Theater Blood. 

2. Capture vitals with remote vital sensing technology and send them to OpenEHR via the Zafe server.

3. Generate patient tracking messages and send them to MedCOP.

name: Multinational Electronic Health Record Management
description:
Experiment with Electronic Health Record (EHR) capabilities in an operational setting including the successful exchange of data between Military Health Information Systems and National EHR Systems using both existing and novel capabilities.

The types of messages to exchange include:

* Field Medical Card (FMC) Messages

* International Patient Summary (IPS) messages

* IPS Mobile Message
 
* Summary Care Record / Request / Response Messages

* Electronic Treatment Messages

* Patient tracking Message

*Smarttag

Goals:

1. Experiment usability testing of Electronic Health Record (EHR) capabilities within an operational setting

2. Experiment in the successful exchange of data between Military Health Information Systems and national EHR systems

3. Experiment with NATO Medical Management Tool to refine integration

4. Exchange of data between Military Health Information Systems and Novel Technology in Medical Support

name: Interoperability test with national and NATO C2 systems through TDL - Green NET
Improve VMF Operational Interoperability
description:
Test interoperability between systems using VMF messaging standard. Ensure proper message delivery and consumption, including the latest updates to the VMF message catalogue.
#The Experimentation dimension addresses new changes to the related standards, such as new message types.
#The Examination dimension addresses maturity of existing implementations in terms of correct handling of all defined message types.
#The capability maturity, in fact, is one of the pseudo-quantities intended to turn out as a result of testing in this OBJ.

name: Improve Link-16 Operational Interoperability
description:
Ensure interoperability between participating systems using Link-16 messaging, with transport based on JREAP-C or SIMPLE protocol. The aim is to guarantee successful message exchange and information consumption.

The test cases supporting this objective may include (but are not limited to):

*Testing the implementation of message exchange with a traffic assessment tool
*Testing the implementation of message exchange with other capabilities
*Testing the message presentation to operators
The Experimentation dimension refers to testing Capabilities having implemented the latest versions of relevant standards.

The Examination dimension applies to most of the testing within the Objective, aiming primarily at identifying gaps in individual implementations.

name: Improve Link-22 over Virtual Radio Technical and Operational Interoperability
description:
The objective is to ensure interoperability between participating systems using Link-22 messaging, with transport based on the virtual radio network (Cloud 22/ NETX22). The aim is to guarantee:

*At the technical level - proper network establishment and management
*At the operational level – proper transmission and consumption of operational messages
Supporting test cases may include:

*Testing the implementation of technical (network maintenance/management) messages
*Testing behavior of Link-22 LLC security component

name: Improve interoperability in multi-standard TDL message exchange
description:
Test message exchange/processing in heterogeneous environment of TDL-enabled systems using different message standards and requiring translation. The results will feed the enhancement process of gateways serving as intermediate nodes.

At the technical level

*proper network establishment
At the operational level

*proper transmission, consumption and forwarding of messages
The Experimentation dimension refers to testing Capabilities having implemented the latest versions of relevant standards.

The Examination dimension applies to most of the testing within the Objective, aiming primarily at identifying gaps in individual implementations

name: Ensure correct initialization via OPTASK LINK processing
description: Test TDL-enabled systems for proper processing of OPTASK LINK messages at the network initialization stage. Identify potential traits which, if left unfixed, can prevent communication within the TDL group being set up

name: TBD
description: Test TDL-enabled systems for proper processing of OPTASK LINK messages at the network initialization stage. Identify potential traits which, if left unfixed, can prevent communication within the TDL group being set up.

name: Improve Link-22 over SIMPLE Operational Interoperability
description: The objective is to ensure interoperability between participating systems using Link-22 messaging, with transport based on the SIMPLE protocol. The aim is to guarantee proper transmission and consumption of operational messages between systems not having the full radio stack implementation ready.

properties.name: ObjectiveLead
values: Sandra Úrsula Luengo,Jesús Manuel Novo Martínez

name: Automated standard conformance testing eXperimentation with SMC standard and INSPECT platform
description:
Experimentation with the new automated standard conformance testing platform INSPECT and the standard SMC.

Goals:

- Validate the latest features of the INSPECT platform.

- Validate the management of the SMC standard artefacts repository.

- Validate the creation of test plans using SMC standard artefacts.

- Verify the execution of SMC conformance tests against actual SMC systems.

- Experiment with the implementation of SMC conformance tests using Robot Framework.

- Experiment with the definition of SMC conformance criteria using different approaches.

- Assess design decisions, technology choices, and security aspects.

- Assess platform infrastructure deployment and configuration.

name: Automated standard conformance testing eXperimentation with DCS standards and INSPECT platform
description:
Experimentation with the new automated standard conformance testing platform INSPECT and DCS related standards.

Goals: 

- Verify the integration with conformance tests, reference system and actual items which implement DCS related standards. 

- Validate the latest features of the INSPECT platform. 

- Allow participants to experiment in order to to obtain feedback regarding new potential features of INSPECT. 

- Assess design decisions, technology choices, and security aspects. 

- Assess platform infrastructure deployment and configuration.

name: Standards Validation: ADatP-4733(B) for FMN Spiral 7 (OD)
description:
Exploring and experimenting with the second edition of ADatP-4733.
The first edition will be a minor step from NVG 2.0.2, however the second edition will be a bigger advancement.
Features of ADatP-4733(B) will include:
* RESTful exchange pattern
* NATO Core Data Framework (NCDF) alignment.

name: ADatP-4733(A) v1.0 DCS Support
description:
''De-risking the NATO Vector Graphics (NVG) specification targeted for FMN Spiral 6, known as NVG 2.0.3. which will be standardised under ADatP-4733(A).''

This objective will test the Draft profile for Data Centric Security (DCS) which is being developped for ADatP-4733(A).

The highlights of the DCS Profile will be:
* Usage of ADatP-5636 metadata in the NVG 'metadata' element of the document element.
* The mandatory metadata elements will be included as mandated by FMN for Spiral 6.
* The binding may bind to any group or symbol element in the nvg document.
* Binding SHALL occur using the xml:id element.
** Possibly additional XPath could be allowed (under investigation)
* All http(s) communication SHALL provide a binding using the 
REST profile defined by ADatP-4778.2 ''(this includes wsdl/xsd exchanges)''
* All SOAP communication SHALL provide a binding using the SOAP profile defined by ADatP-4778.2 ''(this includes GetCapabilities exchanges)''

name: ADatP-4733(A) v1.0 Symbology Binding for APP-6(D)
description:
''De-risking the NATO Vector Graphics (NVG) specification targeted for FMN Spiral 6, known as NVG 2.0.3. which will be standardised under ADatP-4733(A).''

ADatP-4733(A)(1) will be accompanied with an Standards Related Document (SRD) that contains the Symbology Binding between:
* the symbol-standard agnostic exchange of symbols as defined by the ADatP-4733(A)(1) main document; and
* the APP-6(D) symbology standard.

This version contains a large number of fixes as compared to the equivalent bindings to NVG 2.0.2, whilst remaing compatible with thos systems, ''at least for the part that was not broken in the earlier version(s)''.

name: ADatP-4733(A) v1.0 Compatibility with NVG 2.0.2
description:
This objectives verifies that implementations of ADatP-4733(A) are compatible with NVG 2.0.2 on all aspects of the standard that are working for NVG 2.0.2.

The basic premise is that ADatP-4733(A) fixes known issues of NVG 2.0.2, while staying compatible on every other aspect. This means that from an NVG 2.0.2 perspective exchanging information with an ADatP-4733(A) system should be possible to the same extent it can exchange with an NVG 2.0.2 system.

name: ADatP-4733(A) v1.0 Symbology Binding for APP-06(E)
description:
''De-risking the NATO Vector Graphics (NVG) specification targeted for FMN Spiral 6, known as NVG 2.0.3. which will be standardised under ADatP-4733(A).''

ADatP-4733(A)(1) will be accompanied with an Standards Related Document (SRD) that contains the Symbology Binding between:
* the symbol-standard agnostic exchange of symbols as defined by the ADatP-4733(A)(1) main document; and
* the APP-06(E) symbology standard.

name: Conformance Testing: Technical tests using Keyhole Markup Language (KML)
description:
eXamine systems’ conformance to the OGC KML 2.2 Specification.

Some particular testing areas:
* Polling of data/refreshing (KML with network link)
* KML File tests (also without link)
* Support for Icons/Images according to FMN Spiral 4/5/6 they must be inside a KMZ file.
''NOTE in FMN Spiral 6, use of military symbols is explicitly forbidden, in Spiral 4/5 this is implicit''
* Support for Styles
* TLS 1.2/1.3 with network links

NOTE: it is advised all CCs use the same maps using the [[OBJ-038]] provided Web Map Services.
''CCs consuming WMS data must register to OBJ-038 and fill out the [[CC_Catalogue_17|Catalog]].''

name: Test XR Technology, integrating systems and real devices, to support Distributed CP in a 5G Network.
description:
Technologies like virtual, augmented, and mixed reality are evolving fast and more capabilities arising.

The Extended Reality environment is acting as a viewer collecting any information from Simulators, C2 systems, analytic tools, and real devices by using interoperability standards. The use of Artificial inteligence will be crucial to help taking decisions.

Besides, the use of communication interface to allow connectivity through tactical 5G, satellite, Wi-Fi, will support the concept of deployable and distributed Command Posts. The interoperability with Radios is also of great value.

name: Examine FMN Spiral 4 JISR AEDP-18 in terms of GMTI streaming between CSD server(s) and client
description: Examine FMN Spiral 4 JISR AEDP-18 in terms of GMTI (Ground Moving Target Indicator, STANAG 4607) streaming between CSD server(s) and client

name: Explore CESMO and CSD integration
description:
STANAG 4559 Custodian Support Team is developing extensions of 4559 AEDP17, AEDP18, and AEDP19 and new functionality to enable CSD and Electromagnetic Warfare (and especially CESMO) Integration. Those extensions are not part of any standard yet, and the purpose of this objective is to explore possibilities, experiment with implementation, and prepare specifications for the coming 4559 Ed5 and, therefore, FMN SP7.

The principal steps of CESMO and CSD integration (will be elaborated in detail in test scenarios):
# Task CESMO network via AEDP-19
# Publish CESMO stream to CSD via AEDP-18
# Publish CESMO products (C-EOB) into CSD via AEDP-17.

name: FMN Spiral 4 SI for COMMS AV&V
description:
This objective is supporting the AV&V-Process for FMN COMMS Spiral 4.

Participants will demonstrate their technical abilities to configure, deploy and operate a information domain according to Spiral 4 Instructions in all mandatory details.By testing the Communications-Core-Network Interconnection Points functions NIP-N, NIP-CC and NIP-G with there interconnectivity to CWIX counterparts.

name: Information security incidents management on FMN
description:
'''The tests will be conducted Green to Green, Pink to Pink and Green to Pink with the support of Data Diodes and NCDF Diode, thus Green and Pink networks selection.'''

See Document containers for testing diagram.

This objective is about information sharing between Cyber capabilities. This includes information related to observations, cyber events, findings during incidents analysis, request for information, remediation and detection rules. Two standards support structured data exchanges: APP-11-Cyber (under developpment) and SIGMA, a commonly used detection rules description language. Nevertheless, other type of messages can be explored based on CC's capabilities. 
Since Cyber capabilities don't use common information transport mechanism (like email or chat) for security reason, MISP service will be used as the transport mechanism. Use of the NCDF Data Node will also be explored for capabilities implementing APP-11 Cyber.

The outcome of this objective is to validate formated standards, and eventually propose improvements, and to foster thought about the kind of information that can or should be exchanged.

name: (Green) Information security incidents management on FMN
description: The goal of this objective is to examine FMN Spiral 4 requirement 1131 compliance of deployable SOC assets on Green Enclave "Information security incidents on FMN shall be managed", including intrusion detection, system log correlation and incident management.

name: FMN Spiral 4 DNS for PCN AV&V
description:
This is supporting the AV&V-Process for FMN PCN DNS Spiral 4.
Participants will demonstrate their technical abilities to configure, deploy and operate a Protected-Core-Network compatible DNS system according to Spiral 4 Instructions in all mandatory details.
Participants will have to demonstrate interoperability of connected network segments (PCS) on PCN-1 and PCN-2 links on Service-function DNS

A successful AV&V on DNS is the basis for participation in multinational operations.

name: Sharing and Federating of Cyber Threat Intelligence Platforms
description:
The main goal is to create MISP communities according to the ADatP-5660 supporting the FMN Sp6 Service Instructions for CIS Security. '''This objective is cross domain since MISP capabilities will seat on Green and Pink enclaves. There will be some testings Green to Green, Pink to Pink and Green to Pink with the support of cross domain diodes capabilities, thus the declaration of both testing networks'''. Testing will include joining instructions for the participants, CTI information sharing including disclosure protections rules. CTI exchange between MISP and STIX compliant capabilities will also be tested Cross domain tests will also be the venue for testing different diodes or gateways.

Architecture diagram is in document containers.

<u>Expected outcomes</u>: 
* validate the MISP Community scheme, 
* test the Community resilience (when top server out of service), 
* test cross security domains CTI exchange, 
* validate ADatP 5660, 
* test the information dissemination control feature, 
* test MISP as an inter-cyber capabilities data transport mechanism, 
* test relevance of STIX format.

name: eXperiment cross security domain exchange low to high
description: Data from low to high is transferred, ensuring seamless information flow between networks of different security classifications. The experiment will focus on verifying the accuracy, security, and reliability of Cyber data transmitted between unclassified and classified domains. Special attention will be given to ensuring compliance with security protocols to prevent unauthorized access and maintain data integrity during transmission. The outcome will help validate the system's ability to provide accurate situational awareness across multiple security environments.

name: eXpl and eXpe - Advance NATO Space Domain Interop with Space tools - GREEN
description: NATO started implementing the Space Domain and part of the effort is to follow the CFCDGM (Common Funded Capability Delivery Governance Model) to develop a Space Domain Tool capable of providing awareness, sharing data and products and providing planners and decision makers the right information pertaining to Space for joint planning and execution of activities, missions and operations.

name: Examine the provision and consumption of the MD  COP
description:
To examine the provision and consumption of different feed formats from multiple domains: Air, Land, Maritime, Space and Cyber including but not restricted to other Focus Areas: Environmental, Civil, FFT, GeoMETOC, Logistic/Medical, JISR, and also non military areas. Sharing between peer level C2 Systems to ensure that Allied Combined Commands are able to share and integrate the available information collected from their own component commands.

(Previously OBJ-023)Examine the draft ACO directive 080-080 and SCO Reports and Returns for reporting and COP management within the NATO Command structure using directed formats and corrects authoritative data sources or other means of information exchange.

name: Exploring Command Post Support in Maritime Interdiction Operations
description: This objective aims to explore how Maritime Interdiction Operations (MIO) can be effectively supported by command posts through real-time data sharing, post-mission briefings to higher echelons, and the development of a centralized database of MIOs.

name: Air - JISR integration for IRM&CM
description:
The Joint Force Command via HQ AIRCOM issue a Collection Target List for JISR(Air) to prosecute. In order to plan ISR Air Missions, the CTL is imported into an AirC2 system and supported by a Sensor Plan and Line of Sight tool. This enables the Airspace Battle Manager to plan Airspace and Mission Routes for the ISR Air Assets. Subsequently, Intelligence Requirements Management & Collection Management (IRM&CM) is exchanged between the AirC2 system and STANAG-4559 (AEDP-19) compliant system, i.e Coalition Shared Data server or Intelligence Collection Management Tool. 
This objective is to Exercise the existing AEDP-19 interface, and and Experiment with an extended set of AEDP-19 service calls.

EXAMINE - We will examine retrieving a Collection Task Order over the STANAG4559 interface as this is an existing capability that is in use at the NATO ISR Force to NEC CCIS to ensure it complies with the relevant standard in FMN spiral 5

EXPERIMENT - We will test the new elements the NEC CCIS has implement to support the IRM/CM process to manage Collection Requests from a PED node from the NATO ISR Force, through to Air ISR asset mission planning. 

We will experiment issuing ISR Dynamic Tasking via JChat to add additional Collection Requests to the Collection Task Order.

name: Exercise and Examine the planning for Air-to-Air Refuelling using IHub DinoSAAR
description:
Exercise and Examine the planning process and data flow for planning Air-to-Air refuelling. The ACT Innovation Hub will have delivered the DinoSAAR  project by CWIX25 Execution for use in the Air Domain.

EXAMINATION - We will test the soon to be fielded NATO Air to Air refuelling planning tool. This will be scoped to connectivity between the two systems that have been involved during the development process (Innovation Hub DINOSAAR and NATO NEC CCIS). Other systems will be interested in this connectivity as it forms the basis for EXERCISING the capablity.

EXERCISE - We will use an operational realistic scenario for any interested Air C2 systems to exercise Air to Air refuelling planning using Innovation Hub DINOSAAR as the tool doing the heavy planning work of pairing aircraft to tankers.

This is not tagged against an FMN spiral as the capability is algorithm related (internal to DINOSAAR) rather than an interoperability standard. CWIX provides the ideal venue test the output of the algorithmic behaviour using existing standards for communication.

name: NVG 2.0.2 MOR Compliance
description:
With this objective the participating NVG systems will exchange the symbols defined by the Military Minimum Operational Required List (MOR-List).

The MOR List contains around 250 symbols grouped in the following categories:
*Units
*Materiel
*Military Operations Other Than War (MOOTH) a.k.a. Stability Operations
*Task Graphics
*Event Graphics
*Dismounted Individuals

description: This objective includes tests on the NVG functionality to apply styles to area shapes such as polygons, circles, and others.

name: NVG 2.0.2 Content-Item & Composite Tests
NVG 2.0.2 ExtendedData Tests

name: NVG 2.0.2 Metadata Tests
description: This objective includes validation tests for the transfer of structured and standardized relevant data (metadata) for BSOs transferred through NVG.

name: NVG 2.0.2 Technical Conformance Tests
description: This objective includes relevant tests for verifying the structure of elements in NVG, such as entities like circle, polygon, text, etc., as well as other functionalities like timespan, content, etc.

name: ADatP-4733(A) v1.0 Streaming
description: This objective is intended to test the viability of the streaming architecture of 4733(A) v1.0 NVG.

name: JISR 4559 AEDP17/18/19 Use case for AFSC
description:
AFSC is the Alliance Future Surveillance and Control project. 
AFSC would like to test an AFSC vignette against capabilities from JISR FA.
JISR STANAG 4559 is certainly a reference approach/standard of value for capability/Nation federation and bringing ISR into the tactical level through the AFSC use case.
IPR documents include 2 files describing the AFSC use case context. They are also available in AFSC Target Audience.

name: Test formal messaging with New NATO Messaging System (NNMS)
description:
NNMS has been introduced into NCS in 2024 replacing Allied Information Flow System (AIFS)/ Allied Information Messaging System (AIMS) formal messaging system in NATO.

NNMS uses XOMAIL (Military Messaging) and needs interoperability testing.

Federation of XOMAIL systems and establishing Routing Indicators.

name: Consume, display and disseminate logistic data/logistic recognized picture
description: Examine ways and means to consume, display and disseminate LOG data in the form of a recognized LOG picture and/or by other means of presentation (e.g. lists or charts

name: Streaming AEDP18 TDL Exploration
description: Test Streaming TDL through CSD cloud. To look if it is possible to stream Tactical Data Links through a Coalition Shared Data network.

name: SATCOM
description:
Interoperability testing of SATCOM solutions.

Being part of FMN Spiral 6, the Wideband Protected SATCOM based on STANAG 4606 will be test-cased 
and demonstrated. Wideband Protected Satcom is described in TIN-392 - FMN6.

It provides TRANSEC protection against RF transmission jamming, detection, interception and exploitation.

WB BLOS using the SATCOM OTM (On The Move) EPM Waveform
Milsatcom enables NATO Allied Reaction Forces (ARF) in contested environment.

The tests will show your ability to be compliant with Spiral 6.
This is an opportunity for NATO and Nations to ensure their systems are compliant with Federated Mission Networking standards and prove their interoperability for joint operations.

name: STANAG 2591 Advanced Distributed Learning (ADL)
description: STANAG 2591 development and exploration, including Sharable Content Object Reference Model (SCORM), Experience API (xAPI), Computer Managed Instruction 5 (CMI5) and Learning Tools Interoperability (LTI).

name: Enable Communication between CSD on PINK and CSD on FMNEX network
description:
The FMNEX network has slightly different classification and releasability than the PINK network. Therefore, an IEG is required.
This experiment simulates a connection between a system in the operation, in the field, and a system in the reachback, which has an accreditation for a higher classification.

name: Consume, display and disseminate space data/space recognized picture
description:
Recognized Space picture RSpP: 
*use NVG (NATO vectorial graphics with APP-6 binding) for all it is worth in current version
**'''RSpP proposed NVG content''' is described '''HERE: https://tide.act.nato.int/mediawiki/tidepedia/index.php/Recognized_Space_Picture_(RSpP)'''
* check refreshing issue (track propagation is peculiar for space)
Space data illustrate with :
* GNSS (Global navigation satellite system) jamming modelling (part of effect overlays)
* Satellite overfly predictions (part of SA Situational Awareness additional data)
* Space SA briefing material

MDC2 is the prime consumer of RSpP that feeds the common operating picture.

MARITIME showed interest in Satellite overfly predictions so they could produce APP-11 SATVUL messages for units at sea.

The sub-objectives 229 about Orbit data and 237 METOC (METeo OCeanograhpic) data contribute as part of the input data.

Additional JISR (Joint Intel Survey and Reconnaissance) information is also necessary. Spiral 6 does not provide any solution for automation of Intel data yet. The OBJ-238 relative to Space integration in MDO (Multi Domain Operations) will focus on EW (Electronic Warface such as jamming spoofing etc.) to explore this additional topic and go beyond human-readable reports to a more data-oriented intelligence of space interest.

name: Explore and experiment with exchanging MIP information using the Cross COI Data Lake to NVG
description: Explore and experiment with exchanging MIP information using the Cross COI Data Lake to NVG

name: Consume COP from MDC2 and filter elements of space interrest
description:
Space will experiment using COP viewers to filter elements of space interest with a focus on EW

This will be related to JV
* identify jammers to integrate in GNSS jamming modelling
* identify potential threats to space capabilities

Needed CC / POC :
consumer to browse and filter content

name: Experiment Spiral 6 Orbit Data Management
description:
The goal is to validate Spiral 6 specification 
* BP-545 and IERs
** IER-915 swagger for the API
*** Swagger is the web resource as per OpenAPI specifications that declare all dataschemas available, the possible queries and all information needed to implement the API on the consumer endpoint (to include documentation and code elements).
** 6 IER to exchange orbit data that allow to exchange
*** Sensor observations (CCSDS TDM)
*** Orbital catalogues / orbital reconstitutions (current situation, CCSDS OMM as a capsule for TLE or more advanced CCSDS ODM formats) 
*** Ephemerids and patterns of life (past and forecast trajectories)
*** Conjunction data messages
** with at least one green to pink case (external data provider as in Spiral 6)
* TIN-386
** OpenAPI architecture
** DOB : the dataobject is orbit data in JSON files with a recommendation to use CCSDS messages

This objective is strictly about data exposure (IER-915) and exchange (TIN-386). 
However, message standardization is also needed to reach seamless interoperability. CCSDS provides no prescription for json filetype so some variability remains.
To correctly demonstrate interoperability the exchange of orbit data will be played in several runs of the test pattern "double hub" with a source, a gateway, a mission hub and a consumer.

Cross domain considerations
* FMN spiral 6 PI introduce BP-581 external actors processes
** this maps cross domains IER source / destination
* some testing case must be about this
** CC-241 gateway to bring CC-239 data from GREEN to PINK : representative of a service provider WEB to FMN
** CC-107 or 112 NLD to dring NLD national C2 data to PINK : defence partner C2 to FMN

The sibling objective 231 will explore standardizing data and metadata (to include DCS) according to NATO rules for json and schema syntax.

name: Explore and Experiment with sharing information using the NCDF Data Lake
description:
Conduct eXploration and eXperimentation with providing information to other communities of interest (COIs) via the NCDF Data Lake, and consuming information from other COIs via the NCDF Data Lake. NCDF Data Lake enables the sharing of operational information between COIs. Through this sharing of operational information, an improved COP is available to decision makers, resulting in improved operational decisions. Where possible, information shall be made available in consuming systems native formats, thus supporting the communities automated decision support processes.

Validate the NCDF Data Lake API and the resulting benefits of information shared across COIs.

name: Explore : implementing DCS and NATO metadata in Json for Orbit data
description:
The goal is to propose and evaluate json schema for Orbit data with NATO metadata to include DCS labels and binding.

OBJ-229 is about the exchange mechanism.  OBJ-231 is a preparation for future evolutions of the Space C2 specifications to integrate NATO metadata and DCS standards. At CWIX25 the goal is to demonstrate a first step of labeling orbit datashemas with standard metadata blocks and generating binding data objects (BDO). That will make Orbit data message ready to integrate in standard DCS architectures.

Part of the objective is to demonstrate a capability to automate Orbit data analyses that determine if new orbital data is sensitive. The example case will be the analysis of a detected manoeuver to determine if it is normal (unclassified) or suspicious (secret until further notice + the system raises an alert to call human attention). This capability is essential to manage the increasing flow of data in a timely fashion (MDO requires to exchange data "at the speed of relevance" and the increasing congestion of space is a challenge).

Roles : 
*CC-083 as a mission reference orbit database
*CC-472 as a threat analyst (looks for significant manoeuvres)
*CC-114 and CC-236 as consumers to be discriminated (with 4774 labels)
*CC-107 and 112 as gateways to use the labels with (auto security / privacy control)
*CC-127 to activate parallel incident reporting IER (a messge to say a new orbit is a threat to a partner, playes by CC-114)

Linkage to secondary subtasks :
*COI services that enhances mission network
**CC-083 and CC-472 + DCS shall enhance the mission network by facilitating multi-level data exchange
*Systems that develop Datacentricity
**This is the mean to the aforesaid end
*Data integration and interoperability
**CC-083 and CC-472 + DCS shall demonstrate ADatPs were good enough for our dataschemas to be interoperable
*Privacy and security
**That's what DCS enables in a more automated way

properties.name: ObjectiveLead
values: Yves de Lassat de Pressigny,Vincent André

name: Transform Maritime OTH-G to NCDF
description:
TIN-87.
Experiment with transforming OTH-G messages to NCDF format and storing that in one of the NCDF Data Lake nodes. Later on this data could be shred with the systems in NCDF format or transformed into other format like NVG or similar. That greatly improves the interoperability in multi domain environment. 
This OBJ is one from the series of Technology Interactions (TIN), guided by DM CaT.

name: eXpl, eXpe – Cyber C2 information exchange between FMN MNPs cyber C2 and other domains C2
description:
Cyber Prioritized Asset List (CPAL) defined within a MNP is identified as COI services to other nation participants. Objective is to understand how a cyber incident on one COI service hosted within a MNP network may impact the mission assurance from another domain different from the cyber domain.
When an incident occurs, MNP must execute mitigations actions on impacted COI service but it needs first to check those mitigations will not impact the mission and needs to synchronize with Joint level, through the joint cyber coordination team, which mitigations can be executed without impacting another domain planning tasks. Also the cyber picture including the service status and risks on using the impacted CPAL must be disseminated to inform the other domains of the situation to make them take the right decisions about using the impacted service. The cyber picture is updated regularly to inform about the CPAL status and update their decisions on using the service. Also after analysis of the incident, information of interests including discovered threat must be sent to other MNP Cyber C2.

name: Explore and experiment with sharing information in the FNM SP-7 MDO - Technology Interactions (TIN)
description:
Overarching objective to capture all MDO & DT related objectives within the scope of FMN Spiral 7 Technology Interactions (TIN).
Expected maturity of participating CCs is expected to be from experimental to fully operational.
Child OBJs to this OBJ will focus on CBRN, Maritime, OTH-G, FFT, TDL and OPS PLAN data transformation to NCDF format.

name: Transform CBRN MTF to NCDF

This objective will enable CC-Leads to examine their experimental implementation of the MIP-IES v4.5
specifications. The test-results should provide insight in proposed FMN Spiral 6 technical conformance.

This objective is created to support the feasibility demonstration of proposed MIP4.5 Specification for FMN during MIP WG94.
* Schedule: 07-10(11)APR2025
* Site: Greding (DEU) WTD81
* Network: Standalone UNCLASSIFIED enclave
* TestCases: Will be published on Green Wiki till end of MIP WG93.

name: Experiment MET (Meteorological) + Space Spiral6 specification
description:
Experiment Spiral 6 specifications and demonstrate the ability to receive weather and space weather information:
* dataproducts such as alert bulletins and weather situation reports
* data such as georeferenced database or Space weather as data
Check the received information is sufficient and in formats suitable for:
* analyses to provide a dayly space weather report : impact of space weather on Space capabilities and operational space services, as a part of a space dashboard
* automated computing of the availability of space effects at a given time and place
** to cross with satellite overfly prediction to determine actual satellite visibility
** other TBD (could be GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System) blackout, RF (Radio frequency) perturbations or any weather factor with an impact on military effects / capabilities)

Explore what national developmental capabilities would allow to communicate weather and space weather data relevant for space that could contribute to the Space COP

name: Expe Space warfare integration with MDO
description:
Space warfare is about safeguarding blue Space capabilities and possibly exercising control on red capabilities. Threats can originate from any domain and may be out of reach of SpCC own action powers.

Intergrating Space warfare with MDO is essential to preserve operational space support (OSS):
* SATCOM
* ISR
* PNT
* Environmental monitoring (Space based GEOMETOC)
It is also possible to deny RED capabilities without escalating a conflict to orbital warfare which is highly undesirable (against treaties and with high risks of chain reactions).

When operational space support is under threat it is essential to:
* know the relevant part of ORBAT and manage SA against such threat
* manage OSS PACE plans as a contribution to Joint plans
* propose threat mitigation plans
* report on Space functional areas status (OSS and SDA)
* report imminent threat that would require MDO support
* report any outage that requires activating alternate plans

Space proposes to experiment with an EW vignette that would contribute to the joint vignette.

Needed CC :
* Browse COP - CC-018 to CC-371
* Details on ORBAT - CC-050 is related to other EW
* More JISR CSD - TBD at MPC
* Propose plans - CC-014 join 
** FRA CC-472 will have a plan management tool 
* report status - CC-045 for Space SA dashboards (part of space data/picture)
* Report threat - CC-020 CC-011
* report outage - CC-020 for event management +
** CC-011 for messaging 
** CC-045 for Space SA dashboards (part of space data/picture)
** [OBJ-226 will also illustrate modeling GNSS jamming effects]

The same objective will also explore the potential of ISR standards to automate intelligence of space interest data exchange (as a Spiral 7 improvement of current Space intel information exchange requirements).

name: Cross FA Exchange between FFT and MDC2
description: To ingest converted CoT(Cursor-on-Target) data from FFT into a national C2 system (GCCS-A(Global Command and Control System Army)) within the operational FA so that ground level unit data may be available for the command COP

name: Expe OSS C2 functions and SpCC services
description:
To manage the good coverage of Spiral 6 business process 539 Operational Space Support Processes during the exercise.

Operational Space support consists of:
* Space based ISR
* SATCOM
* Positioning, Navigation and Timing PNT
* Space based GEOMETOC datasources

Spiral 6 procedural instruction for Space C2 describe some activities and information exchange at SpCC level (while JISR, Communications or GEOMETOC operate some activities at their own level).

This objective serves 2 further purpose:
* make OSS better known and the workshare in OSS better known (SpCC as a guardian and SDA specialist able to provide some specific services vs. operator swimplanes)
* Check spiral 6 specifications vs. state of the art technology at CWIX

It is fully managed through sub-objectives.
* 238 to link Space plans to Joint requirement for Space support and report any need of MDO support to space 
* 226 relative ro the recognized space picture and data to 
** include OSS status monitoring in the Space SA briefings
** provide additional OSS related situational awareness information focused in space and time such as:
*** GNSS related information (dilution of precision, jamming effects)
*** ISR Satellite overfly predictions
**** This is proposed to be played in a MCC to SpCC format

name: FMN SP-6 Transform NCDF to Native using NCDF API
description:
Conduct eXploration and eXperimentation with providing information to other communities of interest (COIs) via the NCDF Data Lake, and consuming information from other COIs via the NCDF Data Lake. NCDF Data Lake enables the sharing of operational information between COIs. Through this sharing of operational information, an improved COP is available to decision makers, resulting in improved operational decisions. Where possible, information shall be made available in consuming systems native formats, thus supporting the communities automated decision support processes.

Validate the NCDF Data Lake API and the resulting benefits of information shared across COIs.

name: Data exchange - extended APP-11 BL format
description:
Explore, experiment, and examine extending APP-11 data format to incorporate cyber domain data (ADatP-03 Ed A Ver 4 APP-11 Dev). 	- Participating systems should be capable of supporting the export and ingest of the draft NATO standards ADatP-03 Ed A Ver 4 APP-11 Dev and/or NATO APP-06 Ed E Ver 2 (SD1) (STANAG 2019 Ed 8). 

Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) will be pushed from the Green to the Pink through the Diode.

- Examine the use of ADatP-03 Ed A Ver 4 APP-11 Dev to share relevant cyber data between cyber systems.

- Experiment with Spiral 6 COI Services which includes the displaying of the cyber relevant information on the COP. 
- Support Spiral 6 and CPE 593 by transporting Battle Space objects (BSO) the in the Message Text Format (MTF) cyber incident is via multiple mechanisms (email, MISP, Data Lake, Cyber Message Center). 
- Support Spiral 6 and CPE 583 by exchanging Cyber Battlespace Objects using the NATO APP-06 Ed E Ver 1 updates with the cyber symbology.

- Explore Spiral 7+ COI Services by providing mission impact with the cyber relevant information displayed on the COP.

name: Examine interoperability between AFATDS and MSS.

name: Collective cyber defense in the FMN Sp6+ Cyber-Domain Environment

Explore and experiment with collective cyber defense in the FMN Sp6+ Cyber-Domain Environment including: Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) data acquisition; processing; redaction; transport; sharing; mission impact analysis and status' response analysis and status; and experiment with collective cyber defense scenarios.

CTI data will be shared from the Green to the Pink network via the Diode.

description:
The purpose of this objective is to investigate container orchestration and platform engineering.  The areas under investigation relate to standards and technologies.  

Under standards, we need to investigate the compatibility of various container orchestration frameworks firstly, to see if they can work together and secondly, to see if containers prepared for one framework will work in others.

name: DCS STANAG Compliance
description:
As specified in the NATO Vision, data management will move to a Data Centric Security (DCS) approach that anticipates and meets operational requirements at all times through the provision of consistent, secure, accurate and reliable mission data.

A DCS approach facilitates protection at the level of individual data objects, and enhancement to current practice for protecting data mainly at the boundary of a network domain. DCS recognizes that perimeter defence in such an environment is no longer sufficient and moves beyond a gateway defensive posture to address the increasing cyber threat surface presented by cloud platforms, mobile workforce, a variety of device types accessing organizational data assets and a large number of applications and services interacting across the NATO Enterprise. DCS applies another layer of defence-in-depth by directly protecting the data objects, both at rest and while in transit. Along with this enhanced protection, DCS offers a greater level of control for data objects and improved sharing through better data management and exploitation.

In DCS, metadata is used to describe and categorize data, including the security classification of the data, identification of data ownership (and custodianship), retention and disposition, reusability and comprehensibility, and discoverability. For this purpose NATO has specified the NATO Labelling STANAGs (ADatP-4774, ADatP-4778 and ADatP-5636) to provide a common, interoperable and trustworthy approach to labelling across the Alliance.

To facilitate FMN evolving towards milestone 2 and 3, FMN services will be adapted to support the trusted labelling of information shared within the mission. This will leverage the NATO Labelling STANAGs for DCS-enabling core services including SMTP (informal messaging), XMPP (text-based collaboration), Service Management and Control (SMC) and Office Documents and Web Tools (web hosting).

This objective shall include support for the experimentation and examination of partner capabilities that implement labelling functionality for those services that have labelling requirements specified in Spiral 5. This will include the testing of partner capabilities compliance towards the following ADatP-4778.2 Binding Profiles:
*Chapter 3 (SMTP) Simple Mail Transfer Protocol
*Chapter 4 (XMPP) Extensible Message and Presence Protocol
*Chapter 5 (OOXML) Office Open XML Formats
*Chapter 7 (REST) Representation State Transfer
*Chapter 8 (OPC) Generic Open Packaging Convention
*Chapter 9 Sidecar Files
*Chapter 10 (XMP) eXtensible Metadata Platform
*Chapter 12 (XML) Common XML Artefacts

name: DCS STANAG Modification Proposals
description:
This objective will focus on the Modification Proposals for the STANAGs 4774 and 4778. 

Both STANAGs are due for review after five years and modification proposals have been provided to the DCS CaT in November 2024. The modification proposals are based on lessons learned in previous interoperability exercises like CWIX and implementation experience. The aim of the objective is to validate the proposals and improve if necessary.

List of modification proposals:

* Cryptographic Artefact - XMLDSIG (the XSLT is available in the zip archive)
* CMS Cryptographic Artefact Profile
* OPC Binding Profile
* OPC ZTDF Binding Profile
* REST Binding Profile
* WSMP Binding Profile
* XMP Binding Profile

The modification proposals are available in a document container attached to this objective.

For the identity enrollment the following W3C standards will be tested:
https://w3c.github.io/vc-data-model/
https://www.w3.org/TR/did-1.0/

The final goal of the test objective is to find technical possibilities to allow the login based in smart cards and understand all policy and products challenges.
